CNBOnTheMove: -- , - - An island-wide anti-drug operation was carried out from 21 to 26 April 2024. A 16-year-old female Singaporean was amongst the 67 suspected drug offenders arrested. About 572g of cannabis and 222g of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of $62,000. On 21 April, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bukit Batok West Avenue 4 and arrested a 50-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking. From a search of the unit and his rental car parked nearby, officers recovered cash amounting to $9,081, as well as various types of drugs and drug paraphernalia. On 23 April, a 46-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Corporation Drive for suspected drug trafficking. Various drug paraphernalia and drugs including 314g of cannabis and a whole cannabis leaf were found within the unit. Assistant Commissioner Sng Chern Hong, Deputy Director CNB (Policy & Administration), said:Possession of any part of the cannabis plant is an offence. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, cannabis means any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis, or any part of such plant, by whatever name it is called. CNB would like to caution members of the public, that they should not purchase and keep any such part or parts of cannabis plants as it will be an offence under the law.Under Section 8(a) of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to have in his or her possession any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis. If a person is found guilty of possession of cannabis where the quantity is less than 330g, he or she may be sentenced to a maximum of 10 years imprisonment or $20,000 fine or both.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: $ ; , CNB had conducted an operation on 17 April 2024, and arrested a 45-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking. A total of 2,682g of heroin, 20g of Ecstasy, 10g of Ice, 10g of cannabis and two Erimin-5 tablets, with an estimated worth of about $286,000, were seized. The seizure of heroin, Ice and cannabis can feed the addiction of 1,280 abusers for a week. The suspect had a black pouch slung across his body when he was arrested near MacPherson Lane, from which CNB officers later recovered about 239g of heroin. Officers further recovered about 2,443g of heroin, 20g of Ecstasy, 10g of Ice, 10g of cannabis and two Erimin-5 tablets from the mans hideout located near Jalan Chengkek. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were found at the locations for both cases. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug.CNB will not be deterred from carrying out enforcement action against such drug offenders simply because of the anonymity offered by such chat applications. #: . - ; 64 suspected drug offenders were arrested in island-wide anti-drug operations conducted from 18 to 22 March. A total of about 11,467g of cannabis, 1,336g of Ice, 10g of ketamine, six grammes of heroin, three tablets and 82g of Ecstasy, 3,818 Erimin-5 tablets, 46 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 19 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 10 bottles of methadone, with an estimated street value of about $555,000, were seized.The seizure of about 11,467g of cannabis and 1,336g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 2,400 abusers for a week.Locations included a residential unit near Compassvale Walk, where four Singaporean teenagers aged between 17 and 19 were arrested on 18 March. About 16g of Ice, a digital weighing scale, numerous empty plastic packets and other drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the bedroom of one of the suspects, an 18-year-old student. Preliminary investigations found that the 18-year-old was involved in suspected drug trafficking activities and was assisted by the two 19-year-old suspects.In another case, on 21 March, CNB officers intercepted a car along Yishun Avenue 2 and arrested two male suspects: the driver aged 40, and the passenger aged 32. About 9,991g of cannabis, 1,126g of Ice, 10g of ketamine, 82g of Ecstasy, 46 LSD stamps and 3,812 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered from the car. Officers further recovered about 66g of Ice, 2 Erimin-5 tablets and 0.25g of Ecstasy from the 32-year-old mans residential unit near Sembawang Close, and 1,476g of cannabis and 19 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB from the 40-year-old mans residential unit near Woodlands Street 81. <continued below>Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Attending the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) forum with youths from other countries reminded me that we are not alone in the fight for a drug-free world. Megan, youth Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) Did you know that the UNODC organises a Youth Forum every year? Megan, our youth ADA joined the forum held in Vienna this month! She represented Singapore at the forum where a total of 35 participants from 27 different countries attended. Participants attended activities such as learning sessions on evidence-based harm prevention methods and even attended a side event from this years session of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND). The CND is the UNs main drug policymaking body where members meet to review and analyse the global drug situation and recommend measures to address the world drug problem.We are sure that the forum was an engaging one! Thank you, Megan, for representing Singapore.

#: ; . During two separate operations conducted on 5 March, CNB arrested two Singaporean men for suspected drug trafficking offences. A total of 5,651g of cannabis, 975g of heroin, 195g of Ice, 10 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of methadone were seized. The cannabis, heroin and Ice seized can feed the addiction of about 1,380 abusers for a week.One operation saw the arrest of a 54-year-old man within a residential unit near Yishun Street 44, where officers recovered about 975g of heroin, 195g of Ice, 104g of cannabis, 10 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of methadone, estimated to be worth about $167,000. The other operation was conducted at a residential unit near Fernvale Street, where a 29-year-old man was arrested. Officers searched the room occupied by the suspect and recovered about 5,547g of cannabis with an estimated worth of $199,700, and cash amounting to $14,850.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations: The two operations netted a large amount of drugs which could have flowed onto the streets feeding the addiction of a large number of drug abusers and luring new abusers into the downward spiral of drug abuse. Drug abuse is not victimless. Oftentimes, other than the abusers themselves, there are other victims, including their families and loved ones, who have to bear the destructive effects of drug abuse while drug syndicates profit off their misery. CNB is committed to keeping up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers and will continue to target them to prevent harm to individuals and society.Investigations into the drug activities of both suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: -- ; - CNB had arrested 119 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 19 to 29 February. About 1,900g of heroin, 390g of Ice, 453g of cannabis, 8g of ketamine, 2g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 82 Ecstasy tablets, two Erimin-5 tablets, nine LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps and 1g of cocaine, with a total estimated street value of about $343,000, were seized. The youngest arrested was an 18-year-old female drug trafficker.Locations covered included a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 4, where two Singaporean male drug abusers aged 19 and 21 were arrested on 19 February. While CNB officers were conducting a search in the master bedroom, the 19-year-old had charged towards a CNB female officer with a knife from his hiding spot behind the curtains. CNB officers swiftly unarmed the assailant, subdued him and placed him under arrest. He was referred to Police for further investigation for criminal intimidation while CNB continues investigations into his drug offences.On 21 February, four Singaporean males aged between 58 and 69 were arrested at a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 2 for suspected drug trafficking offences. A total of about 1,788 heroin, 19g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia within the unit and strewn (out of the bedroom window) at the foot of the residential block were recovered and seized.[continued in caption below]

3 2023 : 1. 18% increase in new drug abusers arrested in 2023; more than 50% were below the age of 30 years old. 2. Cannabis abusers arrested in 2023 reached a 10-year high , with 17% increase from 2022. 66% of cannabis abusers arrested were new abusers, of which 64% were below the age of 30.3. For new drug abusers, methamphetamine, cannabis, and Ecstasy continued to be the three most commonly abused drugs, with 91% of them abusing at least one of these three drugs. The drug situation in Singapore, while under control, has some worrying trends. With the global drug situation worsening and more permissive attitudes towards drug abuse, we cannot afford to have drugs take root in our society and need a whole-of-community support. The harms of drugs extend beyond what they do the drug abusers, but also affects the well-being of families and innocent children. CNB will be relentless in the fight against drugs. But we cannot stem the tide alone and need the collective support of the public, including parents. Make the right choice and lead a drug-free, healthy lifestyle. Find out about how you can play a part and lend a voice to spread the anti-drug message .drugfreesg linkinbio. Note: 2022 figures are confirmed and 2023 figures are provisional. 2023 refers to the period 1 January 2023 to 31 December 2023. .drugfreesg linkinbio for full stats

CNBOnTheMove: -- Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) arrested three student drug abusers on 6 February 2024. All three had admitted to abusing drugs together on some occasions. The arrest of these student drug abusers highlights a key finding from the Institute of Mental Healths 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, specifically that the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 years of age, while 41.8% of those who abused drugs started before the age of 18.In the early hours of 6 February, CNB officers visited the residence of a 14-year-old girl and arrested her therein for suspected drug abuse. A stained packet was recovered from a search of her room. Preliminary investigations found that the 14-year-old started abusing Ice when she was 13. In addition, a week before her arrest, which was also the last occasion she abused Ice, she abused the drug at home with two other female friends.CNB officers proceeded to arrest the two other girls, both 13 years of age, at their residences. Preliminary investigations found that the two 13-year-old girls had, on occasions, abused Ice at the home of the 14-year-old. One of the 13-year-old had decided to participate in abusing drugs out of curiosity when she saw the other two girls doing so. These preliminary findings further echo the findings of IMHs 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which found that residences ones own home or a friends home were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption and that curiosity was one of the more often cited reasons for drug abuse.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

About 2.6kg of cannabis, 346 tablets and 498g Ecstasy, 842g of Ice, amongst other drugs were seized. The seizure of about 2.6kg of cannabis and 842g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 850 abusers for a week.CAR INTERCEPTION ALONG HAVELOCK ROADIn the late afternoon of 29 January, CNB officers intercepted a car along Havelock Road and arrested the driver of the car, a 35-year-old man for suspected drug trafficking offences. A search of the car recovered about 955g of cannabis and 138g of Ice amongst other drugs. The haul of drugs recovered from the car is estimated to be worth about $118,000.RAID AT BEDOK RESERVOIR ROADIn another operation in the same afternoon, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok Reservoir Road and arrested a 35-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman within the unit. The drugs recovered from within the unit is estimated to be worth about $352,000.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: 15-- 68 ; $63 CNB arrested 68 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 21 to 26 January 2024, among which the youngest suspect arrested was a 15-year-old local student. A total of about 144g of heroin, 112g of Ice and 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of about $63,000, were seized.One of the areas covered included a void deck of a residential block near Bedok North Street 3, where CNB officers arrested a 59-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences on 25 January. The suspect had put up a violent struggle, and necessary force was used to subdue him. About 109g of heroin, 32g of Ice, two Ecstasy tablets and various drug paraphernalia were recovered.Four other Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug offences. Forced entry was effected during the arrest of a 32-year-old Singaporean man and a 19-year-old Singaporean woman at a residential unit near Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3 on 21 January, as the occupant had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. About 154g of cannabis and 5g of Ice amongst other drugs and various drug paraphernalia were seized. In a separate case, CNB officers, acting on information received, raided a residential unit near Pasir Ris Drive 4 on 23 January, and arrested a Singaporean couple, a 42-year-old suspected drug trafficker and his wife for suspected drug offences therein. Officers recovered cannabis, Ice and various drug paraphernalia from within the unit, and from the womans belongings.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; . $ In the afternoon of 2 January, CNB arrested two men for suspected drug trafficking offences. A 53-year-old Singaporean man arrested at a lift landing of a residential block near Jurong West Street 52 had put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and had to be subdued by officers. About 1,396g of Ice, 96g of heroin, 211 Erimin-5 tablets, 94 Ecstasy tablets and one bottle of methadone were recovered from him and a residential unit in the same block.In another operation, a 62-year-old Singaporean man was arrested at a walkway of a residential block in the same vicinity. CNB officers found about 97g of heroin and 31g of Ice concealed on his person.The seizure of about 1,427g of Ice and 193g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 907 abusers for a week.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. CNBOnTheMove: 71 - - 19 24 A total of 71 suspects arrested and about 881g of heroin, 193g of Ice, amongst other drugs and cash amounting to $22,580.15 were seized from the island-wide operation from 19-24 November. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $157,000. The youngest arrested was an 18-year-old suspected male drug offender. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Bukit Batok, Kallang and Punggol. A 24-year-old Singaporean man was arrested for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Pasir Ris Street 11. In the evening of 19 November, during the course of operation, CNB officers spotted the man climbing out of a window of a residential unit located on the second floor in a bid to evade arrest. The man was eventually arrested on the ground level and escorted to his residential unit where about 11g of Ice, various drug paraphernalia, a knuckle duster and a Karambit knife were recovered. Two Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences on 20 November 2023. In an operation conducted in the morning of 20 November in the vicinity of Redhill Close, a 64-year-old Singaporean man was arrested. About 81g of heroin, 13g of Ice and cash amounting to $22,580.15 were seized. In another operation conducted later in the afternoon, a 52-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in his hideout located in the vicinity of Champions Way. About 679g of heroin and 95g of Ice were seized. Forced entry was effected in both operations as both men refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open their doors. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

HAPPENING NOW: HOME TEAM FEST 2023 Come on down to Singapore Expo Hall 4 for a weekend of fun and engaging activities suited for all ages! Learn more about CNBs efforts in keeping Singapore safe from drugs; role play as narcotics officers searching for drugs in a simulated drug hideout! CNBOnTheMove: 2.5 198 $319,000 Seven Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug offences over two operations carried out on 7 Nov. A total of about 2.5kg of heroin and 198g of Ice with an estimated street value of $319,000 were seized. The seizure can feed the addiction of about 1,280 abusers for a week.In the afternoon of 7 November, four men were arrested for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Eunos Crescent. Some heroin, Ice and various drug paraphernalia was seized. A 53-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in the same vicinity. He was escorted to a residential unit nearby where about 596g of heroin, 80g of Ice, and various drug paraphernalia were seized. In another operation conducted the same afternoon, CNB officers arrested a 68-year-old man for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Boon Keng MRT Station, recovering about 17g of heroin from him. CNB officers later arrested a 67-year-old man in the vicinity of Bendemeer for suspected drug trafficking offences. He was escorted to his hideout in a nearby residential unit where CNB officers seized about 1.8kg of heroin and 97g of Ice. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: ; 5.4 Five youths aged between 19 and 23, were arrested for suspected drug offences in an anti-drug operation conducted on 1 November 2023. A total of about 5.4 kg of cannabis, 751g of Ice, 63g of heroin amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of $507,000. The seizure of cannabis, Ice and heroin can feed the addiction of about 1,240 abusers for a week.In the first phase of the operation, a 21-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Buangkok Crescent on 1 November. Almost 2.3kg of cannabis, 216g of Ice, 63g of heroin and other drugs were recovered. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. A 19-year-old Singaporean teenage boy and two foreign men, aged 20 and 21, were arrested in the vicinity of Duchess Avenue in a follow-up operation.In the second phase of the operation, a 23-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Petir Road. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The suspect was escorted to a car and close to 3.2kg of cannabis, 535g of Ice, and other drugs were seized. DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:Yesterdays anti-drug operations saw large seizures of cannabis and other controlled drugs, and the arrests of young drug offenders. Drugs are highly addictive, can destroy lives and tear families apart, but syndicates have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences. CNB is committed to keeping up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers and will continue to target them to prevent harm to individuals and society.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Sgt 3 Lim Zhong Hsien Alvin was awarded the Home Team Diploma (Merit) Award in 2014. Some reflections on his journey with CNB so far:What do you look forward to coming to work in CNB?What I look forward to when coming to work is the profound sense of purpose in knowing that my efforts contribute to promoting a drug-free Singapore. Additionally, I greatly value the camaraderie with my colleagues, and the continuous influx of new challenges keeps my enthusiasm high, while allowing me to give back to the community. Why did you choose to apply for the HT Diploma Scholarship?I applied for the HT Diploma Sponsorship because it resonates with my enthusiasm for law enforcement. This sponsorship not only paved the way for me to begin a career in this field upon the completion of my studies but also offered exciting opportunities for my professional development. It has indeed been a fulfilling and rewarding career journey thus far! Does being part of the team working towards a DrugFreeSG where everyone can live, work, and play safely resonate with you? Check out the sponsorship terms and conditions at

Meet Megan our Singaporean Against Drugs who is also an Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA)! We asked her why she chose to support the cause and here's what she said "At first, it was pure curiosity. I had read many books about crime, and quite a number of them involved drug abuse. As such, I wanted to learn more about drugs, so I could better understand the books I was reading. As I volunteered more, spoke to people that work to help fight against drug abuse, and learnt more about the harms of drugs, I realised that it was a lot more serious issue than I thought it was.Now, I stand strongly by the anti-drug cause as I have learnt the terrible outcomes that it can lead to. Addiction is a scary thing, and it can rip families and meaningful relationships apart. No one deserves to have that happen to them." Want to be an ADA? Find out more .drugfreesg linkinbio SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD PartnerwithHT

CNBOnTheMove: -- - - 134 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 8 to 20 October 2023, including from a joint operation with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA). The joint operation with ICA led to the detection and seizure of about 8.9kg of cannabis. In total about 1.3kg of heroin, 373g of Ice and 9.6kg of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized during the period. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $606,000. The youngest arrested were two 14-year-old boys for suspected drug offences.In the afternoon of 8 October, acting on information, the Police arrested a 14-year-old boy for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Yishun Street 51. About 1g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were recovered. The case was referred to CNB for further investigations.CNB officers launched a follow-up operation later in the same evening and another 14-year-old boy and his brother, a 22-year-old man, were arrested for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Canberra Street. A search was conducted and about 17g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized.In a separate operation on the afternoon of 17 October, CNB officers raided a commercial unit in the vicinity of Serangoon North and arrested a 35-year-old Singaporean man and a 56-year-old Singaporean woman for suspected drug offences. About 979g of heroin, 250g of cannabis and 19g of Ice were seized. Officers then escorted the man and woman to a residential unit in the vicinity of Woodlands Drive 62, where about 25g of heroin were seized.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: - ; . From 3 to 10 October, CNB conducted a series of island-wide anti-drug operations targeted at drug transactions conducted through chat applications, and arrested 47 suspected drug traffickers and abusers. A total of about 5,500g of cannabis, 286g of Ice, 226g and 21 Ecstasy tablets, 2g of ketamine, 291 Erimin-5 tablets, 104 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, and 544g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs, with an estimated value of about $335,000, were seized. The seizure of 5,500g of cannabis and 286g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 950 abusers for a week.Forced entry had to be effected at a residential unit near Spooner Road, as the 36-year-old suspect had refused entry to officers. About 910g of cannabis, 207g of Ice, 28 Erimin-5 tablets, 21 Ecstasy tablets and 544g of powdery substances believed to be controlled drugs were seized.A pair of brothers aged 23 and 18 were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences near Changi Road and within a private residence near Kew Drive respectively. 3,400g of cannabis, 165g of Ecstasy, 263 Erimin-5 tablets and 103 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from the private residence. The 23-year-old man was subsequently escorted to his car parked along Jalan Wakaff, where about 780g of cannabis and 61g of Ecstasy were seized.Other areas included a residential unit near Bukit Panjang Ring Road, where a 37-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug offences. 77g of cannabis and drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the unit and his car in a nearby carpark.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

From 3 to 10 October, CNB conducted a series of island-wide anti-drug operations targeted at drug transactions conducted through chat applications, and arrested 47 suspected drug traffickers and abusers. A total of about 5,500g of cannabis, 286g of Ice, 226g and 21 Ecstasy tablets, 2g of ketamine, 291 Erimin-5 tablets, 104 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, and 544g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs, with an estimated value of about $335,000, were seized. The seizure of 5,500g of cannabis and 286g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 950 abusers for a week.Forced entry had to be effected at a residential unit near Spooner Road, as the 36-year-old suspect had refused entry to officers. About 910g of cannabis, 207g of Ice, 28 Erimin-5 tablets, 21 Ecstasy tablets and 544g of powdery substances believed to be controlled drugs were seized.A pair of brothers aged 23 and 18 were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences near Changi Road and within a private residence near Kew Drive respectively. 3,400g of cannabis, 165g of Ecstasy, 263 Erimin-5 tablets and 103 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from the private residence. The 23-year-old man was subsequently escorted to his car parked along Jalan Wakaff, where about 780g of cannabis and 61g of Ecstasy were seized.Other areas included a residential unit near Bukit Panjang Ring Road, where a 37-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug offences. 77g of cannabis and drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the unit and his car in a nearby carpark.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

FOUR KEY TAKEAWAYS ON THE YOUTH DRUG PROBLEM IN SINGAPORE1. More youths have been arrested in recent operations. 2. The average age at which drug abusers first came into contact with drugs was 15.9.3. More than 40% of drug abusers started taking drugs before they were 18. 4. An IMH survey also found that homes were the most commonly cited locations where people took drugs. Parents and educators must play an important part in raising youths drug awareness and counter misinformation brought about by the liberalisation of drug policies in other parts of the world. Taken from Frontline 2023/2024 Episode 27. Check out the full episode @ CNBPerspectives

CNBOnTheMove: . , . ; On 10 October 2023, a man and woman were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences. About 2.3kg of heroin, 4.1kg of cannabis, 223g of Ice and other drugs with an estimated value of more than $473,000 were seized. The seizure of heroin, cannabis and Ice can feed the addiction of about 1,860 abusers for a week.In the morning of 10 October, CNB officers arrested a 42-year-old Singaporean man and a 35-year-old female Singapore permanent resident at the carpark of a condominium in Boon Keng area for suspected drug trafficking offences. Some heroin, Ice, cannabis, and other drugs were recovered from both the man and the woman. CNB officers then escorted the man and woman to their hideout in the condominium where about 4.1kg of cannabis, 2.3kg of heroin and other drugs were seized. Later the same day, CNB officers escorted the woman to her residence in the vicinity of Yishun Street 51 and seized about 21g of Ice from the unit. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; . In the evening of 5 October, the Central Narcotics Bureau arrested three individuals, aged between 31 and 57, for suspected drug trafficking offences. A 47-year-old Singaporean man was arrested at a void deck of a residential block in the vicinity of Bedok North Street 3 for suspected drug trafficking offences. He was escorted to a residential unit of a nearby residential block located in the same vicinity, where officers subsequently arrested a 57-year-old Singaporean man and 31-year-old foreign woman for suspected drug trafficking offences. About 2,464g of heroin, with an estimated value of more than $259,000, and drug paraphernalia were seized from various locations within the unit. The seizure of 2,464g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 1170 abusers for a week.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: -- - ; , CNB recently mounted a successful operation following investigations on persons who bought drugs via a chat application, arresting 5 suspects and seizing drugs worth about $71,000 and some cash.Forced entry had to be effected at both locations during the op as the occupants refused entry to CNB officers. Subsequent searches of the residential units and suspects cars uncovered various types of drugs, a digital weighing scale, drug paraphernalia and cash amounting to $3,600. Several scheduled weapons were also uncovered and seized.DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:Through our investigations on persons who had bought drugs via a chat application, CNB successfully mounted the operations on 27 September and arrested five persons for their suspected involvement in drug trafficking. Drug offenders who think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously cannot be more wrong. There is no safe haven, whether online or offline, for such nefarious activities. CNB will continue to monitor, track down and take decisive actions against them.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: 15-- 58 - - 58 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 11 to 15 September 2023. The youngest arrested in this island-wide operation was a 15-year-old local student. In total, about 708g of heroin, 670g of Ice, 63g of cannabis, amongst other drugs, as well as cash amounting to $13,390 were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $294,000. In the morning of 11 September, acting on information received, CNB officers arrested a 52-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Marsiling Road for suspected drug trafficking offences. The man was escorted to his residential unit where a search was conducted. Ice and ketamine, and various drug paraphernalia were amongst the drugs recovered from his residential unit and from the mans bag. About 505g of heroin and 13g of Ice were seized from another residential unit in the vicinity of Marsiling Road in the afternoon of 12 September. A 47-year-old Singaporean man and a 36-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences. Forced entry was effected as the occupants refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. Arising from investigations following the anti-drug operations at a Joo Chiat nightspot on 7 September , CNB officers arrested a 28-year-old Singaporean man and a 31-year-old foreign woman for suspected drug offences in the evening of 12 September. The man was arrested in a hotel in the vicinity of Race Course Road where about 15g of ketamine, Ecstasy tablets weighing about 14g, and cash amounting to $9,300 were seized from his hotel room. Later the same evening, CNB officers arrested the woman in the vicinity of Petain Road. CNB officers then escorted both suspects to the mans hideout in the vicinity of Petain Road where more drugs were found. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

: , , CNBOnTheMove: From 7 to 10 September 2023, a series of enforcement operations was conducted at nightspots located in the areas of Joo Chiat, Marina Bay and Bugis. Three male Singaporeans and one female foreign national were arrested for suspected drug-related offences, the youngest being a 19-year-old Singaporean teenager. A total of about 3g of Ice, 98g of ketamine, 46g of Ecstasy tablets and 60g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs were seized.The enforcement operation involved officers from CNB and as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences and crime.Close to 20 persons were checked during the enforcement operations at the nightspot on 7 September. At around the same time, a 29-year-old female foreign national, who was observed by CNB officers to have earlier exited the nightspot, was arrested in a nearby open-air carpark. About 1g of ketamine was recovered from her. In follow-up operations the same night, CNB officers arrested a 26-year-old man in the vicinity of Dunman Road. About 3g of Ice, 46g of Ecstasy tablets, 90g of Ketamine and 60g of powdery substance believed to contain controlled drugs were seized from the vehicle he was in. CNB officers also arrested a 53-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Petain Road, and about 7g of ketamine were recovered from him.During an overnight enforcement operation conducted from 9 to 10 September in four nightlife establishments located near Marina Bay and Bugis, a 19-year-old male Singaporean was arrested for suspected drug-related offences, among over 90 persons checked in the establishments.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: . , . ; - - A 15-year-old girl and a 17-year-old boy were amongst the 130 arrested. In total, about 1.3kg of heroin, 2.5kg of cannabis and 486g of Ice amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were found in the island-wide anti-drug operation from 14 25 August. Cash amounting to $1,503.05 was also seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $453,800. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Kallang, Marine Parade, Pasir Ris and Woodlands.In the afternoon of 14 August, two teenagers aged 15 and 17 and six others aged between 37 and 59, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Woodlands Street 81. Forced entry was effected as the occupants had disregarded the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The two teenagers climbed onto the ledge from the bedroom window of the unit on the second floor in a bid to evade arrest. CNB officers were able to persuade them to return to safety. The other suspects put up a violent struggle during the arrest and had to be subdued by officers. Drugs and various drug paraphernalia were found within the unit and from the ground beneath the unit. In another operation, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ghim Moh Road in the evening of 23 August, and arrested a 24-year-old Singaporean man and a 19-year-old Singaporean woman. About 2.4kg cannabis, 269g of Ice amongst other drugs and vape devices containing drugs were found. A 29-year-old Singaporean man was later arrested in the same vicinity for suspected drug offences. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: , On 9 August, 49 men, aged between 21 and 46, were arrested for suspected drug offences at a hotel villa located on Sentosa Island. officers had acted on information received, and upon conducting checks on the hotel villa, they found substances believed to be controlled drugs at several locations within the villa premises. CNB officers were immediately alerted of the detection. Several substances suspected to be controlled drugs, including Ecstasy and ketamine, and other drug paraphernalia were seized.Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to arrange for gatherings for drug abuse, and it is also an offence for the premise owner, tenant or occupier to permit the premises to be used for drug abuse or drug trafficking.Investigations by CNB into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioOneHomeTeam

CNBOnTheMove: 1 -9 ; OneHomeTeam Three foreign nationals entering Singapore were arrested at Woodlands Checkpoint for suspected drug offences on 2 Aug. The men were stopped for security checks by SPF K-9 officers, who then detected a bundle of cannabis in the vehicle during the routine check. CNB officers were immediately alerted of the detection and arrested the men. In total, two bundles of cannabis weighing about 1,013g were recovered from the vehicle.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. CNB, together with the Home Team agencies, will continue to conduct regular checks and launch timely operations to disrupt any attempts of importation and circulation of controlled drugs in Singapore. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: $, ; On 26 July 2023, CNB officers mounted an operation in Yishun and parts of Jurong. A total of six Singaporeans aged between the ages of 17 and 28 were arrested for drug offences. The drugs seized included almost 1kg of 'Ice', about 7.8kg of cannabis, 1,218 Erimin-5 tablets as well as various quantities of ketamine, 'Ecstasy' tablets and LSD stamps.The 'Ice' seized would have fed the addiction of about 560 abusers while the cannabis would have fed about 1,110 abusers, for a week.DAC Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the island-wide operation:Yesterdays anti-drug blitz to disrupt the operations of drug syndicates saw large seizures of drugs and the arrests of young drug offenders. Syndicates are heartless and have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences that carry severe consequences. CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: - ; --In an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 10 to 18 July 2023, CNB officers arrested 106 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with a total estimated street value of about $17,200. About 223g of cannabis, 54g of heroin, 41g of Ice, 2g of psilocybin mushrooms with spores, 1g of ketamine, five Ecstasy tablets, seven LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, two bottles of GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 27 nitrazepam tablets were among drugs seized.Two young children (aged three and four) were found in a residential unit in Woodlands, where a family of three was arrested for suspected drug abuse: a 57-year-old woman, with her 25-year-old daughter and 21-year-old son. Appropriate arrangements were made for the young children to ensure that their welfare was taken care of - they were later placed in the safe custody of their next-of-kin. Other areas covered included residential units near Fernvale Lane, Potong Pasir Avenue 1 and Jurong West Street 42, where 10 Singaporean youths, aged 17 to 27, were arrested for drug abuse offences. A total of about 26g of vegetable matter believed to be cannabis, 1g of ketamine, seven LSD stamps, cannabis edibles (prepared by sprinkling cannabis onto biscuits) and 2g of psilocybin mushrooms with spores were seized. Preliminary investigations revealed that the six youths arrested near Fernvale Lane may have abused drugs together in the unit on other occasions. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

$ On 5 July 2023 at about 6.40pm, the Police responded to a call for assistance at a residential unit along Jalan Binchang. There, a 28-year-old Singaporean man put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A police officer sustained minor injuries during the arrest. In the unit, the Police found approximately 450g of Ice and 2.2kg of cannabis, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia. CNB officers were subsequently called to the scene and the case was referred to CNB for further investigations. The total amount of drugs seized have an estimated street value of $173,000, and the Ice and cannabis seized can feed the addiction of about 580 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Police investigations are also ongoing for the offence of voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from the discharge of his duty under Section 332 of the Penal Code 1871. The Home Team has zero tolerance towards such acts of violence towards public servants who are carrying out their duties, and will not hesitate to take firm action against those who endanger the safety of our officers.CNBOnTheMove OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

I dont know how to teach him. I dont know how to be a father. But I want to try my best to be a good father.These words would have crossed the minds of every dad, but for John, who led a life wasted on drugs, they are especially poignant, as he looks forward to being reunited with his four-year-old son when he is released this month. We wish John and his son the best.Happy Fathers Day to all dads from all of us at CNB.DrugFreeSGRead Johns story:

#: - ; $ During an island-wide operation conducted from 12 to 16 June 2023, CNB officers arrested 81 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with a total estimated street value of about $60,600.The areas covered included Tampines Street 43, where 469g of heroin, 42g of Ice, 18g of cannabis, cash amounting to $4786.20 and various drug paraphernalia were seized from a residential unit. Forced entry was effected when the occupant refused lawful orders to open the door, and a 61-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

( ): , The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Tax revenues generated from legal cannabis sales constitute less than 1% of the state budget, which is lesser than expected. The retail sale and taxing of cannabis is based on weight, rather than potency, as that will provide more stable tax revenue. However, this opens up a loophole for tax evasion: without regard for public health, cannabis producers and retailers are incentivised to increase the THC* content per gram of cannabis product - to sell high potency cannabis products at a higher price without having to bear more tax costs, thereby maximising profits.States that have legalised cannabis hoped to generate tax revenue, but such income has fallen short of expectations. Meanwhile, the mounting costs of legalisation on public health, emergency services and safety still remain unaccounted for. *THC: The main psychoactive component in cannabis that makes a user feel high.CNBPerspectives :Caulkins, J. P., Kilmer, B., Kleiman, M. A. R., MacCoun, R. J., Midgette, G., Oglesby, P., Pacula, R. L. & Reuter, P. H. (2015). Considering marijuana legalization: Insights for Vermont and other jurisdictions. Santa Monica, CA: RAND Corporation.

( ): The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Legalisation of cannabis has not been successful in eliminating the illegal drug market and organised crime.The illicit market continues to thrive due to factors such as lower prices, wider variety and higher potency of cannabis offered, inaccessibility to the legal markets due to age restrictions and nationality, and buyers unwillingness to register with legal markets.Individuals who are not willing to register or do not qualify for the legal market also continue to buy from illegal drug suppliers active on the internet.CNBPerspectives

( ): , The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Countries that have legalised recreational cannabis use stated that the objectives of shifting distribution to licit channels were to limit availability, and reduce consumption. However, cannabis legalisation has not succeeded in doing so - in legalising jurisdictions, cannabis consumption is still higher, and prevalence of use is increasing more rapidly, with noticeable cannabis-related health consequences. The trivialisation of cannabis use has also resulted in decreased risk perception, i.e. permissive attitudes towards cannabis consumption.CNBPerspectives

( ): , The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Countries that have legalised recreational cannabis use stated that the objectives of shifting distribution to licit channels were to limit availability, and reduce consumption. However, cannabis legalisation has not succeeded in doing so - in legalising jurisdictions, cannabis consumption is still higher, and prevalence of use is increasing more rapidly, with noticeable cannabis-related health consequences. The trivialisation of cannabis use has also resulted in decreased risk perception, i.e. permissive attitudes towards cannabis consumption.CNBPerspectives

#: 145 - Ten youths aged between 16 and 24 were amongst the 145 suspected drug offenders arrested in CNBs island-wide drug operation from 5 to 19 May. About 1.7kg of heroin, 1.4kg of Ice, 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized in total. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $354,000.On 8 May, six youths, aged between 17 and 21, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok South Avenue 2 for suspected drug abuse. Another four youths were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in a hotel in the vicinity of North Bridge Road on 11 May. Superintendent Christopher Lee, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement A and E Divisions, said of the island-wide operation: During this series of anti-drug operations, CNB arrested groups of youths who are suspected to have abused drugs in a friends home or in a hotel room. The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that residences - ones own home or a friends home - were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption. The survey has also found that for those who abused drugs, the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 and 52% of these abusers started out with cannabis. It is crucial for parents and family members to be vigilant to warning signs of drug abuse and help their child seek help early. We strongly encourage parents to have conversations about the harms of drugs with their child early to build up their resilience against drugs and to help our young ones thrive and flourish in a safe and healthy environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

: . , . $ ; CNB officers recently arrested five Singaporeans and seized enough heroin, cannabis and Ice to feed the addiction of about 2030 abusers for a week. The operations were carried out in the vicinities of Senja Rd and Serangoon North Ave 1.Forced entry was effected at one of the locations when the occupants refused to allow officers in.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that for those who abused drugs, the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 and 52% of these abusers started out with cannabis.Members of the public can contact the CNB hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they come across products or consumables suspected to contain drugs or are worried that their children may be involved with drugs.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

"Protect your loved ones from drugs!" Meet some of the Dadah Itu Haram Campaign volunteers who help to advocate for a drug-free Singapore. Their work is not easy as it involves them taking time off their schedules to speak to other members of the public but they continue to contribute to the drug-free cause because drug abuse IS a matter of concern, not just for the abuser, but for those around them. SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

The Institute of Mental Health (.singapore) recently conducted the 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which surveyed 6,509 randomly selected Singapore citizens and PRs on the consumption of illicit drugs in the last 12 months.Here are some of the key findings:1 Age of onset of drug consumption - youngIt is estimated that about 0.7%* of Singapore residents had consumed an illicit drug at least once in the last 12 months. The mean age of onset of illicit drug consumption was 15.9 years old. 41.8% of those who had consumed drugs did so before the age of 18 years old.2 Cannabis as the most common starting drugCannabis (45.9%), ecstasy (21.2%), and methamphetamine (18.5%) were cited as the most frequently consumed drugs. The majority also cited cannabis as the first illicit drug they had consumed (51.9%), followed by ecstasy (18.6%), and heroin (3.2%).3 Prevalence of mental disordersPrevalence of mental disorders were generally higher among those who had consumed drugs in the last 12 months. Such disorders include clinical depression, clinical insomnia, self-reported depression or major depressive disorder, self-reported bipolar disorder, and self-reported anxiety disorder.4 Top reasons deterring drug consumption: Strict laws and awareness of harmsLegal consequences (74.4%), chances of being arrested (65.4%), and awareness of adverse effects on health (65.4%) were the top reasons cited for staying away from illicit drugs.5 Top reasons for drug consumption: Curiosity and peer influenceCuriosity (21.6%) was the most commonly cited reason for consuming drugs. This was followed by the belief that drugs will help with their problems (19.7%), and being influenced by friends (11.9%).6 Most common location for drug consumption: ResidencesThe most commonly cited location for consuming drugs was residences: majority cited that they had consumed drugs at home (30.1%), or at a friends home (19.1%). The third most common location reported was overseas (9.5%). *Figures are based on the prevalence of Singapore residents estimated to have taken drugs in the last 12 months.

#: , $ ; CNB officers recently neutralised drug activities during operations conducted in the vicinities of Jalan Bukit Merah and Tampines Street 22. During the operations forced entry had to be effected into one of the residential units, while a suspect attempted to evade officers by scaling down the kitchen window into a neighbouring unit. The suspect was subsequently arrested.Drugs including heroin, Ice, as well as cash amounting to $36,550, knives, contraband cigarettes and drug paraphernalia were seized from the targeted residential units, suspects vehicles and even locations like the dry-riser outside one of the units.The heroin and Ice seized would have fed the addiction of about 1550 abusers for a week.SUPT William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations, said of the operations:Drug trafficking and abuse pose serious threats to our society. The recent two operations involving large seizures of controlled drugs, dangerous weapons and cash are timely reminders that we must never let our guard down in our fight against drugs. Our officers will continue to remain steadfast in our mission to tackle drug offenders and neutralise drug activities.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: . ; CNB conducted a series of island-wide operations from 11 to 19 April 2023, targeting drug transactions conducted through encrypted chat applications. The more than 11kg of total drugs seized (including 9.5kg of cannabis) had an estimated street value of S$560,000. The areas covered included a residential block near Haig Road, where a 42-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking at the void deck on 11 April. About 783g of cannabis, 17g of Ice, 97g of Ecstasy, 60 Erimin-5 tablets and 13 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from him. Officers later recovered about 8.5kg of cannabis, 766g of Ice, 461g of Ecstasy, 320g of ketamine, 390 Erimin-5 tablets, 56 LSD stamps, 122g of substances believed to be controlled drugs, and various drug paraphernalia from his residential unit.During an operation conducted on 18 April, a 24-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested in a residential unit near Compassvale Link, where about 2.3g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized.On 19 April, 2.8g of cannabis was also seized from a residential unit near Choa Chu Kang Crescent, where an 18-year-old male student was arrested. SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:The use of chat applications that allow for encrypted communication, such as Telegram, has become increasingly popular among drug offenders to buy and sell illicit drugs. Many of these drug offenders think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously. They cannot be more wrong.CNB has observed this phenomenon as early as 2019 and has since arrested more than 500 drug offenders who partake in illegal online drug transactions. Our officers will continue to monitor emerging trends and evasive tactics, and launch well-timed operations to take down drug offenders.Full story at linkinbio

#: ; The 56-year-old Singaporean man has been arrested by the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) on 16 April 2023 for suspected drug trafficking. An arrest warrant was issued for him for his suspected involvement in supplying drugs to associates in Singapore for their subsequent trafficking and sale in Singapore. His involvement was uncovered during the course of CNBs investigation into a drug trafficking case in October 2020, for which the accused (a Singaporean aged 26 at time of arrest) was charged for trafficking in 253g of methamphetamine.CNB had reached out to its foreign counterparts for information on the 56-year-old drug suspects whereabouts, as immigration records showed that he had been out of Singapore since 19 November 2018. He was arrested by the Narcotics Crime Investigation Department (NCID) of the Royal Malaysian Police (RMP) on 31 March 2023, and handed over to CNB on 16 April 2023.In expressing appreciation to the NCID/RMP, SAC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of CNB for Operations, said:The trafficking and abuse of illicit drugs is a transnational problem that requires the close cooperation of the international law enforcement community. Drug traffickers thinking to evade Singaporean law enforcement by hiding overseas will find that there is no safe haven. CNB and NCID/RMP enjoy a close working relationship, as we work towards the common aim of keeping both our countries free from the scourge of drugs. We thank our Malaysian counterparts for the cooperation to bring the suspect back to Singapore to face the law.The 56-year-old man will be charged in court on 17 April 2023, for drug trafficking in relation to the October 2020 case. If convicted, he may face the death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ~. - 161 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide drug operation from 10 to 14 April 2023. About 2,876g of heroin, 209g of Ice, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $234,000. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Hougang, Geylang and Toa Payoh.A 59-year-old man was arrested from his hideout in the vicinity of Lorong 7 Toa Payoh on 11 April. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door. CNB officers recovered about 489g of heroin from the man and seized about 2,067g of heroin, 140g of Ice, 1 bottle of methadone, and various drug paraphernalia from the hideout.Two Singaporean men, were also arrested on 10 April, for suspected drug offences in a hotel room in the vicinity of Geylang Road. About 226g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized. Superintendent Qamarul Zaman Bin Hussin, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drug abuse is a serious threat to our society and if left unchecked, can bring about dire consequences to the safety and well-being of our people. Our officers will not let up our enforcement efforts against drug traffickers and abusers, so that our families and children can live in a safe and drug-free environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Meet Eric, one of our SingaporeansAgainstDrugs! His advice on why you should stay away from drugs "Drugs will take control of your life, enslave and prevent you from fulfilling your fullest potential..." SGAD DrugFreeSG

, - : KK Womens and Childrens Hospital (KKH) (.sg) conducted a systematic literature review of the existing evidence available for drug abuse in pregnancy. The findings revealed that the abuse of methamphetamine (Ice), heroin, cannabis (marijuana), cocaine, 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, or Ecstasy) and various new psychoactive substances (NPS) during pregnancy leads to detrimental maternal, neonatal and paediatric outcomes.The full range of negative effects on the infant/child is summarised in the infographic.The studies in the literature review by KKH acknowledged that many other important factors such as use of more than one drug (polysubstance abuse), poor lifestyle factors, as well as maternal health and nutrition contribute to the above-mentioned negative effects of drug abuse in pregnancy. In light of this, early identification of pregnant drug abusers is crucial. Timely intervention, stopping drug abuse and providing necessary medical and social support can help to reduce the potential risks and negative effects highlighted.CNBPerspectives DrugFreeSG kkhsg kkhresearch

The findings revealed that the abuse of methamphetamine (Ice), heroin, cannabis (marijuana), cocaine, 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, or Ecstasy) and various new psychoactive substances (NPS) during pregnancy leads to detrimental maternal, neonatal and paediatric outcomes.The full range of negative effects on the infant/child is summarised in the infographic.The studies in the literature review by KKH acknowledged that many other important factors such as use of more than one drug (polysubstance abuse), poor lifestyle factors, as well as maternal health and nutrition contribute to the above-mentioned negative effects of drug abuse in pregnancy. In light of this, early identification of pregnant drug abusers is crucial. Timely intervention, stopping drug abuse and providing necessary medical and social support can help to reduce the potential risks and negative effects highlighted.CNBPerspectives DrugFreeSG kkhsg kkhresearch

#: - ; From 31 March to 1 April 2023, CNB led an enforcement operation at nightspots located in the vicinity of Orchard Road and Jalan Sultan. Close to 240 persons in the two nightlife establishments were checked, with saliva test kits deployed to screen for drug consumption where necessary. A 43-year-old Singaporean man was arrested for suspected drug-related offences. The operation also involved officers from the Singapore Police Force and the Singapore Civil Defence Force to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences, crime and fire safety violations. A 31-year-old man was arrested for being a suspected member of an unlawful society.Superintendent Lim Sze Yuk, Commanding Officer of Enforcement G Division, said: This operation is part of CNBs ongoing efforts to clamp down on illicit drug activities. Our enforcement actions at nightspots help keep illicit drugs off Singapores streets and allow members of the public to enjoy Singapores nightlife safely and unharmed by fellow partygoers under the influence of drugs.The introduction of saliva test kits into CNBs suite of tools help increase the testing capacity during our anti-drug operations. Our officers can now choose to deploy the saliva test kits on the spot to supplement other factors before deciding to arrest a person. The test kits are portable and easy to use, and have helped officers make quicker assessment during operations, thereby allowing us to increase the testing rate.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

: ; On 31 March, CNB officers arrested a 39-year-old man for suspected drug abuse from within a residential unit at Ang Mo Kio Ave 3. 1g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from the toilet bowl. In a follow-up operation that same night, officers intercepted a 29-year-old man in a vehicle in the vicinity of Selegie Road. Ecstasy and other drugs were seized. Separately, a 25-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking in a nightspot in the vicinity of Prinsep Street, while five other men aged between 26 and 28 were also arrested there on suspicion of drug abuse.During the operation, a total of about 65g of Ice, 83g of ketamine, a packet of Ecstasy tablets weighing about 110g and 24 Ecstasy tablets and 32g of substances believed to be controlled drugs with an estimated street value of $37,000 were seized.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said The operation is aimed at preventing drugs from proliferating on our streets and nightspots. As activity resumes after the pandemic, the Central Narcotics Bureau has also resumed our anti-drug operations at nightspots Our advice is clear stay away from drugs.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

: ; CNBOnTheMoveOn 20 March, three men and a woman were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Bedok North Road. During the raid, one of the men climbed out the bedroom window of a 9th floor flat to evade arrest. He lost his footing, but was pulled back to safety through the window and placed under arrest. A CNB officer who held on to the man sustained deep lacerations to his right hand while preventing the suspect from falling and was conveyed to the hospital for medical treatment. About 300g of Ice, 238g of heroin amongst other drugs and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from the operation.Another anti-drug operation was also conducted in the vicinity of Bedok North on 20 March following the recovery of significant quantities of heroin from a van that was abandoned by the driver after he crashed it in an attempt to evade a Police enforcement operation. In total, six Singaporeans, aged between 23 and 30, were arrested for suspected drug offences in the two anti-drug operations conducted. A total of about 437g of Ice, 1,322g of heroin, amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of $158,500 were seized. The seizure of 437g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 250 abusers for a week, while the seizure of 1,322g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 630 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: , , . - Following up on information on a suspected drug trafficker, CNB officers were deployed to the vicinity of Ubi Ave 1 on 13 March 2023. Officers raided a unit and arrested a 32-year-old man and a 22-year-old woman. About 345g of Ice, 778g of cannabis, 235g of ketamine, 41 Ecstasy tablets, 100 Erimin-5 tablets, 50 LSD stamps, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered. A large number of weapons including an airsoft pistol, machetes, swords, and knuckle dusters were also seized.During the course of the operation, another 32-year-old man was arrested near Bukit Timah. 5g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from him.The total seizure of 350g of Ice and 778g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 310 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:The operation on 13 March is an example of the dangers that our officers face every day. Drug traffickers may be armed, increasing the risk to our officers. But this will not deter us. CNB officers will remain steadfast in our efforts to prevent drugs from flowing to the streets.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing, and the Police are investigating the 32-year-old man arrested near Ubi Ave 1 for possession of offensive weapons.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; In the early hours of 8 March, Police attended to a traffic accident involving a car and a truck in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 7. The 34-year-old male driver of the car fled the scene and about 55g of cannabis, amongst other drugs together with various drug paraphernalia, and an offensive weapon were recovered from the vehicle and in a bag dropped by the man at a nearby residential block. In a follow-up operation conducted by Police and CNB officers in the same evening, officers arrested a 34-year-old woman in the vicinity of Macpherson who led officers to the man hiding in a nearby residential unit. From within the unit, about 10g of heroin, 7g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized. Upon further checks, CNB officers located a parcel suspected to have been left for the man on another floor in the same residential block, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the parcel.The arrests were part of an island-wide drug operation from 6-10 March 2023 where CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 45g of heroin, 250g of Ice, 250g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $49,000.Superintendent Mohaideen Abdul Kadir, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement J Division, said of the island-wide operation: We must remember that drugs cause harm and suffering not only to those who abuse them, but also to their families. CNB will continue to keep up the momentum of our enforcement efforts to combat the scourge of drugs, and launch timely enforcement operations to neutralise drug activities. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The impact of cannabis consumption is constantly compared to that of alcohol and cigarettes. Is cannabis really the least harmful vice, or is that a common misconception? Reframe your perspectives with some facts and statistics. Find out more: P. I. (2022, November 15). Cannabis smokers more likely to develop emphysema than cigarette smokers. Medical News Today. Retrieved from Hill, K., & Hse, M. (2022, June 14). Cognitive effects in midlife of long-term cannabis use. Harvard Health Publishing. Retrieved from Meier et al. (2022). Long-term cannabis use and cognitive reserves and hippocampal volume in midlife. American Journal of Psychiatry, 179(5), 362-374.Morin et al. (2019). A population-based analysis of the relationship between substance use and adolescent cognitive development. American Journal of Psychiatry, 176(2), 98-106.Whiteman, H. (2017, August 9). Marijuana may be worse than cigarettes for cardiovascular health. Medical News Today. Retrieved from

#: -- In an operation conducted on 21 February 2023, CNB officers stopped and arrested a 32-year-old Singaporean man from his luxury sedan at the vicinity of Bukit Timah Road. A total of about 2.12kg of cannabis, 967g of heroin, 131g of Ice, 123g of ketamine, 263g of Ecstasy tablets, and about 1.32kg of powdery substances believed to contain controlled drugs, with an estimated street value of $182,000, were later seized from his residential unit near Punggol Field. The seizure of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 300 abusers for a week, while the seizure of heroin can feed the addiction of about 460 abusers for a week.SUPT William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations, said:Despite knowing the harms of drugs, drug traffickers continue to peddle drugs and profit at the expense of peoples lives and livelihoods. To prevent and disrupt the circulation of drugs in our society, CNB has in place a comprehensive harm prevention approach including tough laws and robust enforcement to send a strong signal of deterrence against illicit drug activities.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: , Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, who was at the scene where a 2-month old child was found together with her mother, who was suspected of abusing drugs during and after her pregnancy.An island-wide operation conducted from 6 to 17 February 2023 found 133 suspected drug offenders arrested and on 9 February, a 2-month old infant was found with a 32-year-old woman, a suspected drug abuser. The operation was conducted at a residential unit in the vicinity of Sembawang Drive. A small amount of heroin, Ice and various drug paraphernalia was seized from the unit. The woman, who was under investigation for drugs offences since last year, is suspected to have had abused drugs during and after her pregnancy. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the infant was taken care of, and the infant was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, a CNB officer who was involved in the operation, said:As a parent myself, we will always do things in the best interests of our children. I was saddened to learn that the woman may have continued to abuse drugs during her pregnancy, possibly endangering the health of her newborn child. Drug abuse is not a victimless crime it has dire consequences on families and innocent children. I hope that the woman will be able to get the help that she needs, so that she will be able to better care, protect and provide for her child.About 64g of heroin, 528g of Ice, 94g of cannabis, 512g of ketamine amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of about $231,600 were seized from the island-wide operation. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioDrugFreeSG

#: , , A total of about 1,663g of heroin, 1,326g of cannabis and 17 Erimin-5 tablets, with an estimated street value of $183,400, were recovered during an operation conducted on 15 February. The seizure contained enough controlled drugs to feed the addiction of almost 1,000 abusers for a week. A 54-year-old Singaporean man and 45-year-old Singaporean woman were arrested in the vicinity of Clementi West Street 1, where heroin was recovered from their vehicle. About 1.65kg of heroin, 1.32kg of cannabis and 17 Emirin-5 tablets were later seized from their flat near Teck Whye Crescent.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.CNB, together with the Home Team and other government agencies, will continue working tirelessly to neutralise all drug activities in Singapore. DrugFreeSGFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

As one of the strongest supporters of our Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity (AAA), SingaporeansAgainstDrugs, Mr Jay Sng and Mr Mohd Hazli from Ai Tong School explained their motivation behind their consistent support for the activity "Our lifestyles have changed globally and ultimately it will affect Singapore as well. Due to the changing landscape, it is our duty as teachers to make sure that we teach young children to firmly say "No" to drugs so that this will be ingrained and they will look after themselves and love themselves, as well as their families. In addition, we hope our students will understand the consequences of drug abuse and hopefully it will create an impact in the long term." Preventive drug education is extremely important in preventing our children from falling into drug abuse. Find the AAA booklet that can come in useful .drugfreesg linkinbio SGAD PreventiveDrugEducation PDE

- 1. East and South-East Asia are currently among the worlds largest methamphetamine markets. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) reported that in 2021 alone, a record 172 tonnes of methamphetamine was seized in these regions.2. Methamphetamine remains the most commonly abused drug in Singapore. In 2022, methamphetamine abusers made up: 51% of total drug abusers arrested, and 62% of new abusers arrested.3. Increase in cannabis abuse in Singapore as attitudes soften. The number of cannabis abusers arrested in 2022 increased by 71% from 2021. 71% of cannabis abusers are new abusers, of which 70% are below the age of 30. Cannabis seizures in 2022 also saw a 24% increase from 2021. Singapores focus is on building a DrugFreeSG, not a drug-tolerant one. We need everyones support to help communicate the facts and consequences of drug abuse, so that your family and loved ones are well-equipped to make informed choices. Read the full statistics release here:

: - ; CNBOnTheMoveEnough heroin to feed the addiction of about 3,200 abusers for a week was seized in a recent operation conducted by CNB officers. The 6,781g of heroin, which were recovered in several bundles, packets and straws on the 49-year-old suspect, at his residence, at his suspected hideout, as well as thrown out of the windows, were seized along with an assortment of other controlled substances including Ice, cannabis and Erimin-5 tablets.A woman and two other men were also arrested during the operation.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
