#: , ' -- , - ; , During an island-wide operation from 9 to 13 January 2023, CNB officers arrested a total of 88 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of more than $56,000.In one of the cases, a 47-year-old woman, her 48-year-old husband and her 18-year-old son, along with two other Singaporeans, were arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Heroin, cannabis, Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from their home. Preliminary investigations also found that all five persons urine tested positive for controlled drugs.In another case, a 52-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Sultan. An assortment of controlled drugs, including 224g of tampered drink sachets believed to contain methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), were seized from his residential unit and from his vehicle parked nearby. Superintendent Lee Pin How, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement F and L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drugs have a devastating impact on individuals, families and communities abusers are robbed of the opportunity to live their lives to the fullest, relationships are destroyed, and the larger community pays a hefty price in dealing with the wide-ranging consequences that drug abuse can bring. CNB will continue to persevere in safeguarding a safe and drug-free society for our people and our children.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Fully story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: Two brothers, one aged 17 and the other 25, were arrested by CNB officers on 10 Jan 2023. About 1kg of cannabis, 198 LSD stamps, 538 Erimin-5 tablets and other drugs with a total estimated street value of $124,000 were seized.Preliminary investigations revealed that the controlled drugs seized may be linked to drug transactions conducted on Telegram. CNB is aware that some drug offenders and syndicates have been leveraging on encrypted messaging applications like Telegram to conduct their drug activities. These drug offenders may think that such applications can offer them a certain level of anonymity to carry out their illegal activities, and evade CNBs surveillance. CNB is monitoring such developments closely, and has been taking regular enforcement actions against drug offenders who use the Telegram platform for their activities. Regardless of the platform or tactics used in an attempt to evade detection, there is no safe haven for drug offenders in Singapore. Investigations into the drug activities are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG

# - : Did you know that Cannabis Sativa is the botanical name for the hemp plant? You read that right: hemp is cannabis. This means that all hemp proteins, fibre, seeds, oils etc that are derived from the hemp plant are derived from the Cannabis Sativa plant. Despite the product labels indicating otherwise, any product derived from the Cannabis Sativa plant or its seeds can contain controlled drugs such as Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the psychoactive chemical substance in cannabis that causes users to feel high. There have been numerous reports of adverse health impacts linked to its use. Hence, CNB would like to remind importers, retailers and members of the public that any product containing hemp derivatives should not be imported, supplied or put on sale etc. Members of the public who have purchased the pictured Piranha Power Pack Nuts snack product should not consume it, and should dispose of it. They can also contact CNB at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they come across other food products or substances suspected to contain controlled drugs, or make a report to CNB at story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: : 8 , 6 6 Singaporeans were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences on 29 and 30 November 2022. More than 8kg of cannabis, 415g of heroin and other substances with an estimated street value of $304,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 8,194g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 1,160 cannabis abusers for a week, while the seizure of 415g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 200 heroin abusers for a week. In the evening of 29 November, CNB officers arrested a 24-year-old man and a 25-year-old woman, where about 4.9kg of cannabis was found in their vehicle. That same evening, the man and woman were escorted to their hideout in a condominium at Upper Paya Lebar Road, where a 46-year-old man and a 32-year-old woman were arrested. A 54-year-old man who returned to the hideout later that evening was also arrested. About 3.3kg of cannabis, 382g of heroin and other drugs were found. Another suspect, a 41-year-old man, was subsequently arrested at the ground floor of the same condominium block. CNB officers later escorted him to his residence located in the vicinity of Anchorvale Road, where controlled drugs were also found. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, anyone found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; -- During an island-wide operation from 6 to 11 November 2022, CNB officers arrested a total of 96 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $359,000. In one of the cases, a 17-year-old boy was arrested in the vicinity of South Buona Vista Road. Cannabis and drug paraphernalia were found on him and in his residential unit nearby. A follow-up operation by CNB at a residential unit near Lower Delta Road saw the arrest of a 14-year-old boy for suspected drug trafficking offences, and the seizure of cannabis and drug paraphernalia.In another case in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, an assortment of controlled drugs were seized from two Singaporean women, aged 27 and 30 years old, and from their hideout nearby. Ice, cannabis, Ecstasy tablets, LSD stamps were also recovered from a staircase landing on the same floor as the residential unit. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

- , .- MOE educatorsEarlier this year, educators from MOE joined us, CNB Drug Free SG, in a virtual sharing session. The session introduced basic know-hows on how to spot the signs of drug abuse and common types of drugs. An ex-abuser was also invited to share his experience with drugs and his turning point to go drug-free.It takes a whole village to raise a child and this is why it is important for all of us to play our part in protecting our children against the harms of drugs, even in the classroom!SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

: New psychoactive substances (NPS) can contain newly synthesised chemicals designed to mimic the psychoactive effects of existing controlled drugs, and are the second-most commonly abused drugs in Singapore. Earlier last month, CNB added 13 new psychoactive substances (NPS) to the Misuse of Drug Act (MDA) as Class A controlled drugs. Here are 5 key takeaways about NPS use in Asia: Statistics on Ketamine:1. Amongst the seizures of synthetic NPS in 2020, the largest quantities were of ketamine. 2. Most of these ketamine seizures were reported in the East Asian and SouthEast Asian regions: the top 3 countries are Malaysia, Thailand and China (in descending order). 3. Since 2015, the ketamine market has continued to expand in SouthEast Asia, notably Thailand. Statistics on other NPS:4. Other NPS are used and likely on the rise in SouthEast Asia: seizures of synthetic cannabinoids in Singapore have sharply increased over the last 5 years. 5. In 2020, NPS abusers constituted the 2nd largest group (9%) after methamphetamine abusers among new abusers arrested in Singapore. The number of NPS abusers decreased by 7% in 2021. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

I have absolute faith that CNB will remain a formidable force that ensures a Singapore without drugs, where everyone can live, work and play safely. It has been my privilege to be part of the CNB family and serve alongside with a group of extraordinary men and women.- Mr Ng Ser Song (left), Director of CNB, at the Change of Command Ceremony at CNB HQ on 1 Nov 2022. Mr Ng will retire on 6 Nov 2022 after leading CNB for more than 10 years, and Mr Tee Chong Fui Sam will be appointed as Director of CNB.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

CNBOnTheMove TOUGH LOVE: In a recent case, a 14-year-old, accompanied by his father, surrendered about 115g of cannabis at a neighbourhood police post. An additional 52g of cannabis and food products believed to be infused with cannabis were later found at his place of residence. In a follow-up operation, CNB officers arrested two more 14-year-old boys for suspected drug trafficking, one in the vicinity of Clementi Road and the other in the vicinity of Serangoon Road. Officers also recovered food products believed to be infused with cannabis from a residential block in the vicinity of Serangoon Road.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said "... We urge parents to partner us to keep our young ones safe... by talking to them about the harms of drugs, and paying attention to their friends and activities..."Members of the public can contact CNB at its hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. Those who have drug-related information can also call our hotline or submit the information at story .drugfreesg linkinbioDrugFreeSG GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

CNBOnTheMove: Three 14-year-olds and two 16-year-olds were arrested for suspected drug trafficking in recent operations. About 226g of cannabis, estimated to be worth close to $7,000, food products believed to be infused with cannabis, and drug utensils were seized. The teenagers are students from local and international schools.In one of the operations, CNB officers arrested a boy and a girl, both aged 16, for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Bukit Batok Street 21 following ICA officers' detection of a parcel containing suspected drug paraphernalia. About 59g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the girls home.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said: CNB stands firm in our belief that everyone in Singapore should have the right to live in an environment free from the scourge of drugs. We urge parents to partner us to keep our young ones safe. By talking to them about the harms of drugs, and paying attention to their friends and activities, we believe that preventive education is key and CNB will continue to work closely with our partners in schools and the community, so that everyone is made aware of the harms of drug abuse, and can help to spread the anti-drug message and caution their loved ones against getting involved in drugs.Members of the public can contact CNB at its hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. Those who have drug-related information can also call our hotline or submit the information at story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

#: , - During a two-week island-wide operation from 10 to 21 October 2022, CNB officers arrested a total of 117 suspected drug offenders. Among seized items were 24 packets of cannabis sweets, 3 cannabis plants along with their cultivation equipment, and an assortment of controlled drugs.Some of the raids were follow-ups to ICA officers' detection of parcels of candy suspected to contain cannabis.CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is addictive and harmful and is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) 1973. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA 1973. Any person convicted of cultivating the cannabis plant may also face a maximum of 20 years of imprisonment and / or $40,000 fine.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio GuardiansofDrugFreeSG DrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

: On 20 Oct, a man attacked CNB officers with a knife and injured four of them during a raid at a residential unit at Petir Road. Despite their injuries, the officers managed to subdue the man and three of the officers were later conveyed conscious to hospital and received treatment for cuts and lacerations. A knife, and items suspected to be controlled drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized at the scene.The man will be charged in court today (21 Oct 2022) for voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant in the discharge of his duty. CNB investigations into the man's suspected drug-related offences are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam DrugFreeSG CNBOnTheMove

CNBOnTheMove: : ; 13 2 5 suspected drug offenders, aged between 31 and 42, were arrested in 2 operations conducted on 26 September 2022. A total of about 8kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, 2kg of Ice and 2kg of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs, with a street value of about $790,000, are sufficient to feed about 1,180 cannabis abusers, 1,240 Ice abusers and 960 heroin abusers for a week. In one operation in the vicinity of Rivervale Street, CNB officers arrested a Singaporean man. From his vehicle, CNB officers recovered a total of about 6kg of cannabis and other drugs. The discovery included 3 fire extinguishers which had been hollowed out, of which one was found to have contained about 4.5kg of the cannabis. From his residence, another 2kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, amongst other drugs were seized. In another operation, CNB officers arrested 2 Singaporean men in the vicinity of Upper Serangoon View. Both men put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and necessary force was used to subdue them. A total of about 2kg of heroin, 1kg of Ice, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized from one of the mans residence in the same vicinity. A female foreign national who later returned to the unit was also arrested. From the second mans residence located in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 4, about 12g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were also seized. A female foreign national who was in the unit was also arrested. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; In a recent operation on 20 September, two suspected drug offenders hiding in a shophouse climbed out of a window and onto the roof when CNB officers arrived at their door. The suspects were seen running along the rooftop of the row of shophouses putting themselves at risk of serious injury, despite officers warnings to stop. One of the suspects was eventually found in a room in one of the shophouses down the row, while the other was found hiding on the rooftop and brought down safely. Both suspects were arrested. They were escorted back to the unit, where 12g of Ice and offensive weapons such as batons, samurai swords and knives were found. They received outpatient treatment for abrasions and cuts. Investigations indicate that they had consumed Ice, and they were referred to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. This operation was part of a larger island-wide drug operation conducted between 19 to 23 September 2022, where a total of 71 suspected drug offenders were arrested. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 158g of heroin, 77g of Ice, 90g of cannabis, 1g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 28 Erimin-5 tablets and 15 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Kallang and Tampines.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The suspects were seen running along the rooftop of the row of shophouses putting themselves at risk of serious injury, despite officers warnings to stop. One of the suspects was eventually found in a room in one of the shophouses down the row, while the other was found hiding on the rooftop and brought down safely. Both suspects were arrested. They were escorted back to the unit, where 12g of Ice and offensive weapons such as batons, samurai swords and knives were found. They received outpatient treatment for abrasions and cuts. Investigations indicate that they had consumed Ice, and they were referred to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. This operation was part of a larger island-wide drug operation conducted between 19 to 23 September 2022, where a total of 71 suspected drug offenders were arrested. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 158g of heroin, 77g of Ice, 90g of cannabis, 1g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 28 Erimin-5 tablets and 15 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Kallang and Tampines.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: 8 A 42-year-old Singaporean man was arrested by CNB officers at Geylang Road for suspected drug offences on 6 September 2022. The man had put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A total of about 134g of Ice, 1,671g of cannabis, among other controlled drugs were recovered from the 42-year-old man. The man was escorted to two more locations where more controlled drugs were found. In total, about 659g of Ice, 5,093g of cannabis, 442g of ketamine, 252g of Ecstasy tablets, 145 Erimin-5 tablets, 17 bottles of liquid believed to contain 1,195g GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 535g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $343,000. The seizure of 659g of Ice and 5,093g of cannabis is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 1,100 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:CNB will continue to take decisive and firm action against drug syndicates and traffickers seeking to bring harm to our community and profit off the misery of abusers family and loved ones. Drugs have no place in our society, and my officers will stop at nothing to bring those involved in this case to justice.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; , . . - During a recent island-wide operation, CNB officers arrested a total of 134 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $555,000. : In view of the legalisation of cannabis consumption for non-medical purposes in various countries, here are 4 key takeaways about the global demand and supply of cannabis, and cannabis-related crimes. In countries/states where the non-medical use of cannabis has been legalised:1. Perceptions of cannabis harms have decreased; the number of people with cannabis-use disorders (such as psychiatric disorders and suicides) increased. 2. Cannabis consumption among adolescents remains much higher, as compared to countries that have not legalised non-medical cannabis. 3. Cannabis products are becoming more dangerous than ever, as such products with higher potency levels have been found. Cannabis herbs seized in Europe and the US are found to contain increasing levels of THC content over the years. Statistics on Cannabis:4. Cannabis remains the most commonly used and widely produced drug worldwide. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

#: ; . ( , ) On 17 Aug 2022, CNB conducted two anti-drug operations. During the first, at a residential unit in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, two men put up a violent struggle and were subdued with necessary force. A woman who was hiding behind a rack was also promptly arrested. Over 2.5kg of heroin, which was suspected to have been thrown into the rubbish chute prior to the arrests, was also recovered. Another 1.1kg of heroin was also seized during a second operation in the vicinity of Fernvale Street.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

"Hi! We are a group of students from Singapore Polytechnic School of Business . We are excited that we were given the opportunity to work with CNB on our "Adventures of Piller Parker" , an anti-drug social media campaign! Our campaign features a huourous and candid cartoon character "Piller Parker" (inspired by superhero Peter Parker a.k.a Spiderman), who is passionate (and sometimes perhaps a little too excited) about spreading the anti-drug message. The campaign gave us a good opportunity for us to leverage the skills that we've learnt in school, pick up new skills and apply them in real-life to positively impact our community. Working with CNB also made us more aware about drug issues in our society and the negative impacts of drugs. Each of us can play a part to keep ourselves and our friends away from drugs. We are grateful to have this opportunity to work with CNB to play a part in this!" SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

: , , Over 300 officers from CNB, HTX, HSA and ONCB Thailand received an MHA National Day Team Award for over 20 ops conducted between 2019 and 2022 targeting drug activities using chat apps. : CNBs annual statistics release 2021 show methamphetamine (meth) to be the most commonly abused drug in Singapore: 58% of drug abusers arrested in 2021 were meth abusers. Meth abusers also made up the largest proportion of NEW abusers arrested in 2021 at 76%. Taking a look at the global drug situation, here are 2 key takeaways about meth use. 1. Methamphetamine remains the most used amphetamine-type stimulant (ATS) in the SouthEast Asian region, with almost 200 000 people being treated for meth abuse. 2. Meth seizures in SouthEast Asia saw a 30% increase from 2019 to 2020. Myanmar reported the highest increase, followed by Malaysia. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

, : The World Drug Report is published by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) annually. It provides a yearly overview of major developments in drug markets, drawing insights from trends and statistics about drug production, trafficking and consumption. Drug issues that require intervention from government agencies worldwide are also flagged. The UNODC released the World Drug Report (WDR) 2022 recently. It is reported that the current generation of adolescents continue to use more drugs than adults, and exhibit higher levels of drug use as compared to past generations of adolescents. In the subsequent posts of this WDR 2022 series, get the lowdown of drug issues around the world through bite-sized infographics! These posts will highlight some of the most commonly abused drugs in Singapore: cannabis, methamphetamine and new psychoactive substances (NPS).CNBPerspectives WDR2022

Meet the SP students from the School of Architecture and Built Environment who organised an internal SP event "The Best Me, is Drug-Free" "Our event was an internal event for students, by students. Just like the name of the event, we wanted to spread the message, "You are your best without drugs!" to encourage peers to stay away from drugs. Working on this project, we were given various opportunities to liaise and coordinate with external organisations, which was really not easy. #: - ; In a recent op, CNB officers went to a 11th storey unit and knocked on the door and identified themselves. A female occupant was then seen climbing out the window of the unit and scaling down to the 8th storey, near the aircon ledge.An officer immediately rushed to a stairway near the subjects location and calmed her down such that she did not endanger herself any further. She was subsequently rescued unharmed by SCDF officers and warded in hospital for observation as she was 7 months pregnant.With her safety ensured, officers then gained entry into her unit, where they found her 7-year-old son alone, along with drug paraphernalia. Arrangements were made for the welfare of the boy, and he was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.A heart-wrenching scene for all involved - the suspected abuser, the child, and the officers, all except for the trafficker who had been profiting off her addiction.For a DrugFreeSG

CNBOnTheMove: ; -- In the evening of 13 July, CNB officers arrested a man in the vicinity of Bedok North Avenue 3. The suspect put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and attacked officers with a pepper spray. Officers responded with necessary force and subdued him. Officers searched the man, and two of his hideouts situated in the vicinity of Siglap Road as well as Yishun Ave 11. A total of about 141g of heroin, 181g of Ice, 11 Ecstasy tablets and 21 Erimin-5 tablets, with a total estimated street value of $47,000, were seized during the operation. Offensive weapons including a knuckle duster, two Karambit knives and a pepper spray were also recovered. The seizure of 141g of heroin and 181g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 170 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

I joined as an Anti-Drug Advocate because I firmly believe that drugs have no place in our society. For CNB's Anti-Drug Abuse Campaign 2022, I was invited to conduct an interview with Prof Faishal, to raise awareness on the event. Having learnt about the adverse and irreversible effects of drugs, as well as the penalties that are set in place for those who committed drug abuse, I will like to continue to spread the important message of staying away from drugs.- Dervin Lua, from Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) Swipe right and scan to watch Dervin's interview with Minister of State, Associate Professor Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim. Check out .drugfreesg's linkinbio to find out more about ADA's anti-drug advocate movement today!SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG ADAC2022 ItStartsWithUs

#: ; . In the late afternoon of 4 July, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Suspects refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door and forced entry was effected. The 5 men were arrested. About 39g of Ice and 9g of heroin, along with cash amounting to $6,000, were recovered from the 57-year-old man, the registered occupant of the unit. About 31g of heroin was recovered from the 58-year-old man, and a small amount of Ice was also recovered from the 55-year-old man. An estimated 1,023g of Ice, 107g of heroin, 1g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from various locations in the unit during the search of the unit. A total of about 1,062g of Ice, 147g of heroin and 1g of cannabis, with a total estimated street value of $223,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 1,062g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 600 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full Story .drugfreeesg linkinbio

Make Your Pledge for a DrugFreeSG at our Pop-Up Booth this week! This year, we've setup a booth in conjunction with our annual DrugFreeSG Light-Up, which is held on 26 June in solidarity with the UN's International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking. There, you can pledge your support for a drug-free Singapore by placing an anti-drug ribbon into an interactive pledging mechanism, and you'll also get to experience two immersive rooms that mean to highlight the harms of drugs in an experiential manner. Do drop by at Suntec East Atrium (Tower 3) between 10am to 9pm from now till Sunday to show your support!

Distressing scene: Baby found near drugs during op at abusers unitIn a recent op, officers found a drug abuser and her 9-month-old son at her unit. She had been abusing Ice in close proximity of her baby and was the sole caregiver. Living conditions were squalid and drug paraphernalia were found in the open.The baby was brought back to the station and provided with childcare necessities like milk powder by officers. The baby has since been handed over to Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) as the abusers parents are unable to take care of him, while the abuser will be committed to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC).Such scenes, though rare in Singapore, are a stark reminder that those who deal in drugs destroy lives.For a DrugFreeSG

CNBOnTheMove: Drugs worth $55,000, including 173g of cannabis, seized in recent island-wide ops as Singapore Government maintains clear stand on illicit drugs CNB recently concluded a two-week island-wide drug operation which covered areas including Jurong, Marine Parade, Sengkang and Yishun. A total of 146 suspected drug offenders were nabbed.During the operation, controlled drugs of about 28g of heroin, 234g of Ice, 173g of cannabis, a small amount of ketamine and cocaine, 10g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 11 Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, and a bottle of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $55,000. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.The Singapore Governments stand on illicit drugs, including cannabis, is clear - they are harmful, addictive and can destroy lives, families and communities. Examples of other countries have clearly shown that a permissive attitude towards the use of drugs exacts a high cost on society. Therefore, there are strict laws against the trafficking, possession, consumption, and import or export of illicit drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products. CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) in Singapore. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA.Full story:

We are so honored to be mentioned at CNB Drug Free SG s workplan seminar Thank you for the opportunity to spread anti-drug messages especially to the younger audience and parents. We are also extremely grateful to the support from neighbours and the community We hope more people will come onboard to support a Drugs Free Singapore During the CNBs annual workplan seminar on Tuesday (May 31), Minister of State for Home Affairs highlighted the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) plans to strengthen Singapores anti-drug enforcement efforts through the use of technology, continued engagement and community supervision programs. Full speech by Assoc Prof is here In conjunction with the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (also known as the World Drug Day) that falls on 26 June every year, we are collaborating with the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and rally the communitys, especially the younger generations support for a drug-free Singapore. Here are some publications you can find at the library:Be Careful, Max! A Story about Stranger Dancer (for preschoolers ages 4 to 6)Captain Drug Buster & Dr. Wacko: The Origin (For children aged 5 to 8)Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The Final Showdown (For children aged 7 to 10) Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity Booklet (for ages 9 to 12) Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The First Encounter (For youths aged 13 to 16) kNOw Cannabis information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors) New Psychoactive Substances information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors)Information toolkit (for parents) Lets all play our part in creating a drug-free Singapore! You can visit or follow CNB on Facebook and Instagram cnb.drugfreesg to find out more about activities planned for the month of June!onehometeam drugsfreesg clementiridgeslibrary clementiridges cnb captaindrugbuster

' : , $. In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's ops and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021.We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore.We look forward to your continued support!OneHomeTeam for a safe, secure and DrugFreeSGFull news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:

Drug abuse is not a victimless crime. Addiction can cause psychological and physical harm not just to yourself, but also to your loved ones. We must learn to protect ourselves, our friends and family from falling prey to misinformation about the harmful effects of drugs. DareToCare! You can start by spreading anti-drug awareness through meaningful stories to inspire our community to get StrongerTogether against drugs and drug abuse. Join the DrugFreeSG Video Competition, tell a meaningful story today .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSGVideoCompetition SayNoToDrugs DrugFreeSG

-: - , - In a recent operation, a suspected drug offender climbed out of her third-story window and jumped down onto the second-story parapet. She then attempted to scale down the parapet wall despite warnings from CNB officers below, putting herself at risk of serious injury. An officer quickly moved a nearby trash-bin in place to cushion her descent and she managed to land safely. She was placed under arrest and subsequently brought to the hospital for a check-up. Investigations indicate she is suspected to have consumed heroin not long before officers arrived at her location.

18 ; CNBOnTheMove OneHomeTeamOn 18 May 2022, ICA officers foiled an attempt to smuggle about 17,704g of heroin, 261g of Ice and 2g of Ecstasy tablets in an arriving Malaysia-registered car via the Woodlands Checkpoint. The driver was arrested. CNB officers mounted follow-up enforcement operations and arrested two other suspected male Malaysian drug offenders in Singapore over 18 and 19 May. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $1,295,000 and is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 8,430 heroin abusers and 150 Ice abusers for a week.Full story: (linkinbio)

#: , $ - CNB recently concluded a 5-day island-wide operation to disrupt drug syndicates and target abusers.In one case, 20kg of cannabis and 6.2kg of heroin were seized. Two Singaporeans and a Malaysian man were arrested. Most of the drugs seized were uncovered at one of the traffickers' hideout in an apartment block in the vicinity of Braddell Hill.The operation also covered other locations including Ang Mo Kio, Bukit Batok and Yio Chu Kang. The total amount of drugs seized during this operation is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,960 heroin abusers, 410 'Ice' abusers and 2,910 cannabis abusers for a week.AC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of Central Narcotics Bureau (Operations), said:"Singapore's open economy and connectedness as a regional transport hub, and its proximity to major drug-producing regions, places it in constant danger of being overwhelmed by an influx of narcotics. While the drug situation in Singapore is relatively under control, we cannot take this for granted.This latest haul of drugs has disrupted the syndicates, and CNB will continue to keep up the pressure on them. We are also controlling local demand with our dragnet operations targeting drug abusers."Full story:

#: ; Over 4kg of suspected illicit drugs, including some which were found hidden in tampered milk tea sachets, were seized in a hotel room in the vicinity of Bras Basah Road during a recent CNB operation.In the evening of 9 May, CNB officers raided the hotel room and had to effect forced entry. A 31-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the bathroom, where he was suspected to have been disposing of illicit drugs into the toilet bowl. Packets of cannabis, as well as other drugs, were recovered from the toilet bowl, cistern and drainage, as well as in other parts of the hotel room.A total of about 65g of Ice, 2,155g of cannabis, 5g of ketamine, 360g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 1,310g of Erimin-5 tablets and 700g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The seizure of 2,155g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 307 abusers.Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said:It is not surprising that drug trafficking syndicates have continued to exploit various novel drug concealment methods to evade CNBs persistent enforcement actions. In this operation, we saw how syndicates have tampered milk tea sachets to hide their drugs. CNB will spare no efforts in launching well-timed operations to prevent these drugs from contaminating our society. We will also carry out our duty to prevent unscrupulous offenders from enticing the unsuspecting public and youths to consume these drugs.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story:

#: . , On 26 April 2022, three Singaporean men aged between 20 and 22 were arrested for suspected drug activities by CNB officers. One of the men was escorted to a locked riser in the vicinity of Eunos Crescent, where, using a key found on him, officers unlocked the riser and recovered about 2,312g of heroin.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Full story:

If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Full story:

#: , 60, . 735 254 In the afternoon of 22 April, CNB officers arrested a 61-year-old man in the vicinity of Serangoon Road. About 245g of Ice was recovered from him, along with cash amounting to close to $3,400. In a follow-up operation, two other men (aged 65 and 67), and a 65-year-old woman were arrested in the same vicinity. A total of about 521g of heroin, 3g of Ice and cash amounting to more than $1,500 were recovered from the 67-year-old man. The 65-year-old man and woman were escorted to their hideout in a private residential estate in the same vicinity, where about 214g of heroin, 6g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the residential unit. Cash amounting to more than $12,000 were also recovered from the 65-year-old man. The seizure of 735g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 350 abusers for a week, and the seizure of 254g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 150 abusers. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, if a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine) or 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story: (linkinbio)

CNBOnTheMove: 32 - In an island-wide operation from 18 and 19 April 2022, CNB officers arrested 32 suspected drug offenders, The operation was targeted at drug transactions conducted through chat applications. Areas covered during this operation include Bukit Panjang, Compassvale, Jurong West and Sembawang.A total of about 191g of Ice, 718g of cannabis, 4g of ketamine, 4g of cocaine, 714g of Ecstasy tablets, multiple LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 201 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $140,000.In one of the cases, CNB officers arrested a 26-year-old man in the vicinity of Bukit Batok West on 18 April evening. The man was escorted to his residence in the same vicinity, where a total of about 173g of crystalline substances believed to contain Ice, 488g of cannabis, 713g of Ecstasy tablets and other drugs were seized. A 24-year-old man who later visited the same residential unit was also arrested for suspected drug offences. SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of CNBs Intelligence Division, said: CNB had carried out a similar operation in November last year, targeted at drug transactions conducted on encrypted chat applications where 50 suspected drug offenders were arrested. Drug offenders naively assume that these chat applications can afford them the anonymity to facilitate their illegal activities, so that they can evade CNBs detection but they are wrong.This latest operation shows that CNB is not letting up on our efforts against drug offenders, regardless of whichever methods they use to mask their activities.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

CNBOnTheMove: 84 - ; 231 , 304 ' In an island-wide operation from 10 to 14 April 2022, CNB officers arrested 84 suspected drug offenders across Singapore in areas including Hougang, Telok Blangah, and Yishun. A total of 231g of heroin, 304g of Ice, 36g of ketamine, 113 Ecstasy tablets, eight Erimin-5 tablets and 16 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of more than $70,000. The youngest arrested is a 16-year-old male Singaporean for suspected drug abuse.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 and arrested a 55-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers. A total of about 174g of heroin and 6g of Ice, along with various drug paraphernalia, were seized from the unit. On the same day, CNB conducted a follow-up operation to arrest the 55-year-olds drug clients. Two Singaporean men, aged 44 and 45, were subsequently arrested in the same vicinity.SUPT Mohd Hamzah Yusop, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 1, said of the island-wide operation: This island-wide operation is part of CNBs sustained commitment to keep our streets safe from the scourge of drugs. Our officers have been diligent in following up on all drug leads, and we will spare no effort to track down both drug traffickers and drug abusers.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

"I'm currently volunteering at a faith-based drug rehabilitation support movement for women. At 13, I started taking drugs because I felt rejected by my family. My health deteriorated and I ran into trouble with the law.The birth of my son and my journey with my faith turned my life around. Both helped me to accept, love and protect myself. Thereafter, my health was restored. My advice to others who are tempted to try drugs - Learn to recognise the potential obligations of peer pressure. Starting with e-cigarettes, alcohol abuse, it may escalate to pills. Never feel ashamed to seek help from trusted people."- Hannah Chun SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD

CNBOntheMove: 9 , 0.5 ; In the afternoon of 30 March, CNB officers arrested a Malaysian man in the vicinity of Beach Road, and about 4,876g of cannabis was recovered from him. The man was escorted to his residence where an addition of about 3,877g of cannabis and 463g of heroin were also seized.The total quantity of 8,753g of cannabis seized can feed the addiction of about 1,250 abusers for a week, while the 463g of heroin seized can feed the addiction of about 220 abusers for a week.Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said: The drug seizures in this operation serve as a reminder of our firm zero-tolerance approach towards drugs, including cannabis. Cannabis is an illicit drug in Singapore. It is addictive, and its use can produce several harmful effects, such as irreversible brain damage, brain volume reduction, and serious mental / psychiatric illnesses.Beyond their physical effects, illicit drugs exact a heavy price on our families and communities. Livelihoods are lost, relationships are destroyed, and families are broken.In order to protect our society from the harm of drugs, CNB will continue to enforce strict laws against the trafficking, possession, consumption and import or export of illicit drugs. CNB will also not let up on our enforcement efforts to arrest drug abusers who purchase drugs from syndicates.Investigations are ongoing.Full Story: (linkinbio)

CNBOntheMove: - ; , In an island-wide operation from 14 to 23 March, CNB arrested 100 suspected drug offenders across Singapore in areas including Choa Chu Kang, Macpherson, Seng Kang and Tampines. A total of about 279g of heroin, 404g of Ice, 6,308g of cannabis, 237g of ketamine, 2g of new psychoactive substances, more than 709g of Ecstasy tablets, 197 Erimin-5 tablets, 19 LSD stamps and 200ml of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $382,000. The youngest arrested is a 16-year-old male Singaporean for suspected drug abuse.At one particular location in the vicinity of Jalan Damai, a 22-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug-related offences. About 3kg of cannabis was seized, along with other drugs, as well as several knives, a chopper and an airsoft gun which were found in his room. He was then brought to his official place of residence nearby where various drug paraphernalia and another airsoft gun were seized.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said of the island-wide operation: CNB has worked tirelessly to stem the flow of drugs to keep Singapore safe. Our officers have put in a lot of hard work to bring drug offenders to justice, even amidst dangerous and unpredictable situations involving offenders who may turn violent against them. At CNB and the Home Team, we believe that drugs have no place in Singapore, and we are committed to keep our streets safe from drugs.Investigations are ongoing. Full Story: go.gov.sg/100suspectsarrested25mar2022 ( )

: - . .In a follow-up operation on 16 March 2022, 11 suspected male drug abusers (comprising four Singaporeans and seven foreigners) were arrested. A total of about 280g of cocaine, 54g of cannabis and cannabis seeds, 33 Ecstasy tablets and 245g of brown powder suspected to contain controlled drugs were seized in the operations. Superintendent Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said:Drug abuse is a persistent threat that targets every vulnerable segment of our society. It exacts a heavy price on abusers, their families and our community. This is why Singapore takes a zero-tolerance approach towards drugs to prevent harm to our people and society, and to create an environment where our children can live and play safely. Those who visit or live in Singapore must abide by our laws. If they choose to break them, they must be prepared to face the consequences. CNB will not hesitate to take action against these drug offenders and will keep up our enforcement efforts. Our message is clear - there is no place for drugs in our society.Investigations into the drug activities of all 14 arrested suspects are ongoing. CNBonthemove Full Story: go.gov.sg/300gcocainebooksmar22cnb ( )

#: - ; , During the operations that took place on 4 and 5 March, 3 men (aged between 50 and 55), and a 29 year old woman were arrested. CNB seized a total of about 1,494g of heroin, 428g of Ice, 78g of cannabis, 326g of Ecstasy tablets, 303 Erimin-5 tablets and 3g of Yaba tablets. These drugs had a total estimated street value of $221,000.The 55 year old and 50 year old were caught when CNB officers intercepted the vehicles they were respectively driving near Chai Chee Street and North Canal Road on 4 March. In a followup ops the same evening, CNB officers raided a unit in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 3 and arrested a 54 year old man. A 29 year old woman was arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Eunos in the early hours of 5 March.Drug paraphernalia and weighing scales were also seized during the ops. Superintendent William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of CNBs Intelligence Division, said of the operation: The drugs seized from this operation can feed the addiction of about 1,000 abusers for a week. But the harm goes beyond this number. Illicit drugs are harmful and addictive, and the despicable actions of drug traffickers can destroy lives, families and communities... CNB will continue with our targeted operations against drug syndicates to prevent drugs from flowing into the streets. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine) or 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the suspects drug activities are ongoing.Read more here:

#: 93 - During the operations that took place from 27 Feb to 4 Mar, controlled drugs of more than 1kg of heroin, and others were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $78,000.Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Tampines and Toa Payoh.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Circuit Road, and arrested two men aged 40 and 51 for suspected drug offences in the late evening of 27 Feb. As officers moved in to arrest the 51-year-old man, he put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to subdue him. A knife was also later recovered from the 40-year-old man. About 3g of heroin and 2g of Ice were seized from the 51-year-old man. Another 946g of heroin and various drug paraphernalia were seized in another residential unit that the 51-year-old man was escorted to.In another case on 28 Feb in the vicinity of Clementi Ave 3, 8 persons were arrested including a 71-year-old man and his 49-year-old daughter. The father and daughter pair were arrested for suspected drug consumption. SUPT Mohd Hamzah Yusop, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 1, said of the island-wide ops : Drug offenders who think they can evade from the enforcement actions of CNB are mistaken. Our officers have worked hard during the week-long operation, and we will continue to launch timely and co-ordinated operations to keep our community safe and drug-free.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Read more here:

Meet CNB officer SSI Che Yahya Bin Mohd Bujang and his fellow (DIH) colleagues! SSI Yahya joined CNB in 1987. Over the last 35 years, he has chalked up a wealth of experience in the Enforcement, Supervision and Intelligence Divisions of CNB.He was also part of the pioneering team at CNBs Community Engagement Unit. SSI Yahya was closely involved in the launch of the DIH campaign in 2017. Together with other CNB officers and the community, they travelled around to rally the community, going the extra mile to support DIH volunteers in spreading the anti-drug message. Despite restrictions brought about by Covid-19, his team persevered with online sessions to sustain the engagement. For his significant contributions, commitment and dedication, SSI Yahya received the Efficiency Medal at the recent National Day Investiture held for MHA officers. Congratulations, SSI Yahya!SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG DadahItuHaram

#: , $ , . On 25 February 2022, CNB officers raided a residential unit in a private residential enclave in the vicinity of Upper Serangoon Road and arrested three men for suspected drug activities. Large quantities of cannabis, Ice, heroin, cocaine and other drugs with a total estimated street value of $726,000 were found in the unit. Investigations into the suspects drug activities, including an investigation into their financial activities to trace and forfeit proceeds and property from the drug activities, are ongoing.AC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of Central Narcotics Bureau (Operations), said of the operation:Drug syndicates and traffickers are motivated by greed and will capitalise on the addiction and misery of drug abusers for profit. To them, drug abusers are revenue streams to cultivate and exploit, and they do not care that their actions are at the expense of innocent others such as the children or loved ones of the drug abusers. My officers remain committed to the mission of keeping Singapore drug-free, and will continue to clamp down on these illicit drug activities.Full News Release:

"To be an MVP on and off the field, stay clear of drugs.Last Saturday, SINDA FC (Singapore Indian Development Association) held a football training session for youths together with CNB officers, and there was also a candid dialogue with participants on the drug situation in Singapore. Our officers also shared their personal and work experiences with the youths, highlighting the importance of maintaining a healthy and drug-free lifestyle. This collaboration was part of CNBs community outreach efforts under the Bothaiporulai Ethirthu Nirpom (BEN) campaign.*The BEN or Bothaiporulai Ethirthu Nirpom (We Stand United Against Drugs) campaign is one of CNBs Preventive Drug Education community outreach efforts. BEN seeks to spread the anti-drug message to the Indian community. This is done through face-to-face engagement with people, as well as in partnership with volunteers, community groups and media personalities who warmly step forward.: the BEN teamSingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG BEN BothaiporulaiEthirthuNirpomWeStandUnitedAgainstDrugs

[ ] Amidst a challenging global and regional drug situation, Singapore remains steadfast in adopting a comprehensive drug control strategy for a DrugFreeSG. This is done through preventive drug education, tough anti-drug laws, rigorous enforcement, international engagement, and rehabilitation and aftercare of drug offenders. While the number of drug abusers arrested in 2021 decreased by 11%, the proportion of new drug abusers and young drug abusers arrested remained significant. The international drug scene remains of concern too, and Singapore is located at the doorstep of the worlds largest drug producing region. Amid COVID-19 travel restrictions, drug trafficking syndicates continued to look for novel ways to bring drugs into Singapore. Nonetheless, drug seizures remained high in 2021 and are indicative of CNBs effective enforcement efforts. In 2021, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates. CNB also worked closely with the Home Team agencies to conduct more than 100 joint operations, including at the checkpoints, to intercept attempts to smuggle drugs into Singapore. COVID-19 did not put a stop to CNBs preventive drug education efforts. The fundamental principle underlying Singapores approach against drugs is to prevent harm to our people and society in the first place. This is much more effective than letting the drug problem grow and fester. Singapore takes a zero-tolerance stand against drugs because it is the best approach for Singapore, and it has helped keep the drug situation under control. Drug abuse can exact a heavy price on abusers, their family, and ultimately society, and the focus hence has to be on building a drug-free society, not a drug-tolerant one. CNB will continue to work closely with the community, and keep up our efforts to prevent drug abuse. Lets work together to keep Singapore DrugFree for future generations! Read the full statistics release here: go.gov.sg/cnb-annual-statistics-2021Highlights of CNBs Preventive Drug Education efforts in 2021 can be found here: go.gov.sg/cnb-annual-statistics-2021-annex

#: , On 28 and 29 Janurary 2022, a total of about 3.8kg of Ice, 1.8kg of cannabis, as well as Ecstasy tablets and other illicit drugs with a total estimated street value of $768,000 were seized during a CNB operation. Three men aged 38, 48 and 58 were arrested.A suspected drug store in an industrial building, where drugs were hidden in packages of coffee beans, was also uncovered. Large quantites of drugs were also found in the residence of one of the suspects.Drug producers in the region are producing more drugs. Those intending to import and traffic these illegal drugs here into Singapore and intending to bring harm to our community will be dealt with by the law. My officers will be thorough in bringing those involved in this case to justice. - AC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of CNB The seizure of 3,862g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 2,210 abusers for a week, while 1,873g of cannabis is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 270 abusers for a week.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Read more here:

#: - On 20 Jan 2022, ICA officers foiled an attempt to smuggle about 7g of cannabis and cannabis products in a parcel declared to be cosmetic products. The products were sweets believed to have been infused with cannabis, and vaporisers containing cannabis extracts. CNB officers conducted a follow-up operation the same day and a 24-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested in the vicinity of Upper East Coast Road for suspected drug-related offences. 24 LSD stamps and two vaporisers containing cannabis extracts were further seized. Investigations are ongoing. Cannabis is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) in Singapore. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA. CNB would like to urge parents to play an active part to protect our youths from the menace of drugs, and to remind their children that they should not consume products unknown to them or offered by strangers. To entice youths to consume these products and to become addicted to them, these products are often disguised or marketed as candy or other food products, and sold in bright packaging designed to appeal to children and youths. Members of the public are advised to contact the CNB hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they come across such illicit food products, or are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. Those who have drug-related information can make a report to CNB by calling 1800-325-6666 or at more:

100 , 8 In a recent island-wide operation, CNB officers seized a large quantity of drugs, including about 5,640g of heroin, 1,744g of Ice, 1,308g of cannabis, 5g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 24 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, more than 3,000 Ecstasy tablets, 654 Erimin-5 tablets, and three bottles of methadone. 100 suspected drug offenders were also arrested.CNB officers will continue to keep a close watch on the ground for drug activities and continue with our robust enforcement to deter drug traffickers and take them off our streets. Our laws are tough and well known. Anyone who chooses to harm others by selling and trafficking drugs know the serious consequences that their actions will bring. - AC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of CNB The total amount of drugs seized in the operation is sufficient to feed 2,690 heroin abusers, 1,000 Ice abusers and 190 cannabis abusers for a week. ' ' , On 5 Jan 2022, CNB officers arrested five Singaporeans, comprising four men aged between 61 and 65, and a 65-year-old woman, for suspected drug trafficking activities. A total of about 932g of heroin and 5g of Ice, worth an estimated $66,000 on the street, were seized during the operation. Most of the drugs seized during the operation were found in coffee packets recovered from a toilet bowl at a residential unit in the vicinity of North Bridge Road, as well as from a rubbish chute nearby.A quantity of 932g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 440 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing. Full Story: DrugFreeSG

CNBOnTheMove: On 3 January 2022, Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) officers foiled an attempt to smuggle 5.8kg of kratom leaves in an arriving Malaysia-registered lorry via the Woodlands Checkpoint. This prompted subsequent enforcement operations by CNB. A total of five male suspects (a 33-year-old Singaporean and four Malaysians aged between 27 and 40), were arrested at multiple locations in Singapore over 3 and 4 January.Kratom contains Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which are both Class A controlled drugs under the Misuse of Drugs Act. Investigations into the drug activities and suspects are ongoing. Read more here:

CNBOnTheMove: , 2 In a recent op, CNB officers arrested two men aged 37 and 59 for suspected illegal drug activities. A total of about 1,867g of heroin, 216g of Ice, 68 Ecstasy tablets and 12 Erimin-5 tablets, worth a total estimated street value of $167,000, were also seized. Superintendent Lim Sze Yuk, Commanding Officer of Enforcement G Division, said: Illicit drugs are harmful, addictive, and can destroy lives, families and communities. This is why we have strict laws in Singapore against the trafficking, possession, consumption, and import or export of illicit drugs. CNB officers will continue to take rigorous enforcement and launch well-timed operations to keep the streets of Singapore safe from drug traffickers and syndicates. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. 1.8kg of heroin can feed the addiction of about 890 abusers for a week, while 216g of Ice is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 120 abusers for a week.DrugFreeSGRead more here:

CNBOnTheMove: -- - In a 3-day island-wide drug operation from 8 to 10 December 2021, CNB arrested 63 suspected drug offenders. The youngest arrested is a 17-year-old male Singaporean suspected drug abuser. The total drugs seized are about 209g of heroin, 299g of Ice, 733g of cannabis, 10g of ketamine, 9g of NPS, one LSD stamp, one Erimin-5 tablet, and two bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB. The drugs have an estimated street value of more than $70,500.During the search in the drug raid around the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Street 22, CNB seized 12 packets and 107 straws containing 195g of heroin (see Photo). DrugFreeSG Read more here:

, , , , - Minister Lee Hsien Loong was speaking at todays CNB50 Anniversary Event, which was held to mark the Bureaus achievements over the past 50 years. He also unveiled a commemorative stamp set*, as well as a commemorative coffee table book.CNB was first set up in 1971 as the primary drug enforcement agency in Singapore. For more information, visit and *Members of the public can purchase the stamps from all post offices, Philatelic Stores and online atshop.singpost.comfrom 7 December 2021.

-? - Chat apps like Telegram are fun ways to connect with lots of people. But drug syndicates and suppliers have been using such platforms to seek out new clients and reconnect with existing ones, thinking such apps will allow them to evade the law. This time, 50 suspected drug offenders have been arrested, including a 20-year old Singaporean male. Investigations are ongoing. This is a reminder that we've been watching and taking action. Just stay away from drugs. Full Story here: DrugFreeSG

' : ; - Acting on information provided by CNB, the Narcotics Crime Investigation Department (NCID) of the Royal Malaysian Police (RMP) arrested five Malaysians for suspected drug trafficking activities in and around Kuala Lumpur and Selangor. The drugs had an estimated street value of RM 4.9 million. Monitored by CNB since July 2021, the Malaysian-based syndicate was believed to have been trafficking drugs using Singapore-based freight forwarding companies, as legitimate forwarding agents, to deliver parcels which contain concealed drugs to other countries through Singapore. The swift arrest was the result of the strong collaboration between CNB & NCID, RMP. CNB will continue to maintain close international cooperation with law enforcement agencies for a DrugFreeSG. CNBOntheMove Full Media Statement: go.gov.sg/cnb-ncid-oct2021IntheNews: Press Conference: ,

CNBOntheMove Full Media Statement: go.gov.sg/cnb-ncid-oct2021IntheNews: Press Conference: ,

CNBOnTheMove: Two 22-year-olds among 6 arrested for suspected drug trafficking activitiesIn two drug busts on 7 Sep 2021 in different parts of Singapore, four males aged between 22 and 55 and two females aged 22 and 35 were arrested for suspected drug-related activities.A total of about 2,804g of heroin, 109g of Ice, 225g of cannabis, 212 Ecstasy tablets and fragments, and five Erimin-5 tablets were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $222,000. The total amount of 2,804g of heroin seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 1,335 abusers for a week.Full Story:

CNBOnTheMove: , , In a two-week island-wide operation from 16 to 27 Aug 2021, 161 suspected drug offenders were arrested at areas including Lakeside, Potong Pasir, Seng Kang, Teck Whye and Woodlands. The youngest arrested was a 17 year-old Singaporean female suspected of drug abuse.Drugs estimated worth more than $253,000 were seized with a total of about 3,069g of heroin, 544g of Ice, 53g of cannabis, 37g of ketamine, 31 Ecstasy tablets, 116 Erimin-5 tablets, and 11 bottles of methadone.Full Story:

IntheNews: . Drugs hidden in buttons? As reported in Lianhe Wanbao (19 Aug), Tokyo Metropolitan police arrested three individuals who attempted to smuggle 2.6 kg of drugs, estimated to be worth $1.88 mil, with 1331 buttons. Each button held about 2g of drugs and were sewn onto 73 pieces of clothing. The clothing were shipped from the UK to Tokyo in the first half of August.Indeed, drug syndicates will try ways and means to traffic drugs, to profit off addiction. Our officers will remain alert and vigilant to ensure that our streets remain drugfree.

CNBONTHEMOVE- 12 arrested during CNB Anti-Drug Operations; Drugs seized estimated to be worth more than $152,000In the latest drug bust on 3 and 4 August 2021, a total of about 624g of Ice, 2,375g of cannabis, 53g of ketamine, 413 Ecstasy tablets and fragments, 602 Erimin-5 tablets, 226 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 161g of substances believed to be controlled drugs, and 116 bottles containing liquid believed to be laced with controlled drugs were seized in multiple locations in Singapore. This is CNBs second anti-drug operation targeted at drug syndicates in a week eight suspected drug offenders were previously arrested on 27 July 2021, which saw the total seizure of close to $749,000 worth of controlled drugs.The total amount of Ice and cannabis seized from both the 27 July, and 3 and 4 August operations are sufficient to feed the addiction of more than 2,150 abusers for a week.Investigations are ongoing. Read more:

BAKING TROUBLE YET AGAIN - 42 baked goods and crumbs believed to be infused with cannabis seized, along with other drugs CNBONTHEMOVE In the latest drug busts that took place in multiple locations in Singapore on 27 July, CNB officers seized a total of about 42 baked goods and crumbs believed to be infused with cannabis, 2.5kg of Ice, 164g of cannabis, 7g of ketamine, 54 Ecstasy tablets, 9,831 Erimin-5 tablets, 5 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, and 111 packets containing substances believed to be controlled drugs. Various drug paraphernalia were also recovered in one of the operations.A total of 5 males and 3 females were arrested for suspected drug-related activities.Investigations are ongoing.Read more here:

*Drum Roll* Announcing the winners of our IG-filter Light-up contest! Thank you all for your support and participation in the contest! However, due to overwhelming response, we were only able to choose 3 participants as the winners! :( For those who were unable to come down for our Drug-Free Light-Up on 26 June, we hope that you had fun using the IG-filters with the iconic buildings and monuments lighted up green and white- the colours of our anti-drug ribbon! If you have missed this contest, fret not as we have more contests with attractive prizes coming your way! For a DrugFreeSG!

Hurry! The DrugFreeSG Video Competition 2021 will close at 2359 hours on (). Remember to submit your entries via The results of the competition will be announced on 6 Sep 2021 (Mon). Good luck and all the best!

- - -- - CNBONTHEMOVEIn an island-wide operation from 12 to 16 Jul 2021, CNB officers arrested 104 suspected drug offenders and seized a total of about 1.8kg of 'Ice', 535g of Ecstasy' tablets, 191g of heroin, 5g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) and 6 Ecstasy tablets. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $198,000. Three very young children were also found during the operations and in close proximity to where suspected illegal drug consumption or activities had taken placed. Their welfare was taken care of and they have been placed in the safe custody of their next-of-kin.One of them was a 10-month-old baby. An officer who was at the scene (pictured) had this to say - "As a father to two daughters, I instinctively knew that the baby needed to drink milk when I saw her crying. It saddens me to see such innocent victims being brought up in such an environment. This is the reason why CNB officers are motivated to give our best in our work"News release:

It is a fine sunny day until you stumble upon a cave in the woods, leading to 3 different entrances. There are different drugs lying before you, but what awaits behind their tempting facade is a rabbit hole of irreversible danger. Will you fall down that spiral? CNB has collaborated with the Singapore Press Holdings to develop a new interactive gamification, Down the Rabbit Hole. Find out more about the harmful effects of different drugs now at Make the right choice. Dont fall down the rabbit hole.

CNBOnTheMove: CLOSE TO 1KG OF HEROIN SEIZED IN CNB OPERATIONIn the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 5 July 2021, a total of about 974g of heroin, 3g of cannabis, and 60g of suspected New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) were seized. Cash amounting to $57,929 and 330 nitrazepam tablets were also recovered during the operation. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $102,000. The total amount of 974g of heroin seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 460 abusers for a week. Two Singaporean suspected drug offenders, comprising of a 65-year-old male and a 55-year-old female, were arrested.Investigations are ongoing. Read more:

Happy Youth Day to all youths (and the young at heart)! DidYouKnowPlay helps children work through stress and worries. Play benefits physical and mental health, and it helps maintain some normality in difficult times.Studies suggest that children who lack emotional support and endure stressful situations are more likely to experience toxic stress, which is associated with mental health problems, substance abuse and low amounts of play. ListenFirst DrugFreeSG ParentingTipsHow are you celebrating Youth Day?

CNBONTHEMOVE - MORE THAN 10KG OF CONTROLLED DRUGS SEIZED; FOUR ARRESTED FOR SUSPECTED DRUG ACTIVITIES In the latest drug busts by Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers on 30 June 2021, a total of about 7,959g of heroin, 2,159g of Ice, 423g of cannabis, 202g of ketamine, about 1,451 Ecstasy tablets and about 300 Erimin-5 tablets were seized during the operation that took place in multiple locations in Singapore. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $1.18 million.Two Singaporean males and two Malaysian males were arrested for suspected drug activities.Investigations are ongoing. Did you know that our Anti-Drug Abuse Campaign (ADAC) in Singapore has been ongoing for more than 25 years? This is how we commemorate World Drug Day (26 June) annually! Were always heartened to see how individuals from all walks of life come together to pledge for a DrugFreeSG, be it through enjoying the Light-Up, carnivals, dance competitions, or other ground-up initiatives. Click through for a journey through past ADACs this FlashbackFriday/ThrowbackThursday!Come 26 June, buildings around Singapore will get lit in solidarity for a DrugFreeSG! Were definitely glad to have our partners on board again for this year's DrugFreeSG Light-Up and we hope youre ready to enjoy it too.Also, do keep a lookout for our upcoming DrugFreeSG Light-Up Instagram Filter Contest where you can pledge your support for a DrugFreeSG and win attractive prizes!

DidYouKnowFamily rules are a set of principles laying out what behaviour is expected of the family members. When applied lovingly and correctly, these rules can help the whole family get along.Research shows that parents who are loving and supportive but expect compliance with rules, and are both consistent and fair in their discipline, have more well-adjusted and resilient children. On the flipside, a lack of structure and insufficient limit-setting can put children at greater risk of problem behaviours (including drug/substance abuse). ListenFirst DrugFreeSG ParentingTips

Check out these behind-the-scenes photos of the creators of the VR mobile game app - students from . Hear what inspired them to develop Man in the Mirror and contribute to the drug-free cause! The team wanted something different from existing efforts. We wanted to see if we could build a game that would help players empathise with the vulnerability of falling into substance abuse and addiction, with the aid of VR technology. However, all this would not have been possible without the story. While crafting the story, the team had many discussions on what we should focus on, be it pre- or post-abuse. We also considered the perspectives of abusers. Ultimately, we want to convey to our audience that prevention is better than cure, and inspire a sense of hope for those who wish to break free from addiction. ICYMI: The giveaway contest on Facebook is still ongoing till 4 June 2021! Like, comment a screenshot of the Man in the Mirror on your mobile devices, and hashtag DrugFreeSG for a chance to win a customised VR cardboard headset!

Is this what you want your life to be forever? These were the very words that changed an ex-drug abusers life.In this months edition of IN Magazine (distributed to secondary school students), ex-drug abuser Mr Ismadi shared his personal story on how his mother helped him turn over a new leaf.Theres also a fun mini-contest within! Submit your entry and stand a chance to win an exclusive goodie bag!All secondary schools subscribed to IN magazine would have received the e-paper by now. If you have not, you can find the e-copy here: saynotodrugs

CNBOnTheMove: OVER 10KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS SEIZED; 2 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 25 May, a total of about 5.6KG of heroin, 2.5KG of Ice, 2.5KG of cannabis, 192 Ecstasy tablets, and seven Erimin-5 tablets were seized. Cash amounting to $28,000 and 703 nitrazepam tablets were also recovered during the operation, which took place in the vicinity of Fernvale Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $944,000. Two Singaporeans a 45-year-old male and a 31-year-old female, were arrested for suspected drug activities. Prior to the raid, two children, an 11-year-old boy and 10-year-old girl, were playing outside the unit. They were later established to be the children of the 31-year-old female suspect. Arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the children were taken care of. The children were subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Children are the unfortunate victims in many of such drug offences. Drug traffickers not only destroy the lives of others through their selfish and nefarious acts, but also bring pain and misery to their family and children. Parents play a key role in nurturing and guiding their children, and to keep them out of harms way. CNB endeavours to keeping the streets of Singapore safe from drugs through our rigorous enforcement actions and will continue to reach out to parents and work with them to guide their children towards a healthy, drug-free lifestyle. Mr Sebastian Tan, Deputy Director CNB (Operations)Investigations are ongoing.

CNBOnTheMove: OVER 7KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS SEIZED; SEVEN SUSPECTS ARRESTEDOn 18 May, CNB officers conducted two operations which saw the seizure of a total of about 5KG of Ice, 2.2KG of heroin, 6g of cannabis, 1g of ketamine, more than 630g of Ecstasy tablets, 201 Erimin-5 tablets, and one LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamp, along with cash amounting to $4,585. Seven suspected drug offenders, comprising six males and one female aged between 26 and 48, were arrested. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $850,000. The operations took place at multiple locations, including in the vicinity of Jurong East Ave 1, Chai Chee Street and Lorong Limau. Investigations are ongoing. Photo 1 (CNB): Illicit drugs, including Ice and Ecstasy tablets, recovered from a safe in the vicinity of Lorong Limau on 18 May 2021.Photo 2 (CNB): About 466g of heroin, which was concealed inside a fire extinguisher, seized from a residential unit in the vicinity of Jurong East Ave 1 on 18 May 2021.

ABOUT 1.7KG OF CANNABIS SEIZED; 6 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest CNB operation conducted on 15 and 16 Apr, a total of about 1.7KG of cannabis, 104g of Ice, eight Ecstasy tablets and 20 Erimin-5 tablets were seized. Six suspects aged between 26 and 33 were arrested.
