DidYouKnowActive listening is when a caregiver listens to their child with the intent to listen and not to jump in and respond. Active listening is important during times of stress and can reduce fear and anxieties. Children who receive attention (especially at an early age) grow more confident, less anxious, and are likely to achieve better health, relationships and education. ListenFirst DrugFreeSG ParentingTips

CNB STATEMENT ON ONLINE VIDEO CLIP OF SUBJECT ALLEGEDLY ABUSING DRUGSThe Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) is aware of a video clip circulating online of a female subject allegedly consuming drugs using an apparatus. CNB has identified the subject, and she is currently assisting in investigations. She has been released on bail into the custody of her parents. As investigations are ongoing, the public is advised not to circulate the video. Everyone, including parents and the community, has a role to play in protecting our youths from the harms of drugs. More information and useful toolkits on how to spot warning signs of potential drug problems, as well as how to effectively engage young people to stay drug-free can be found on the CNB website ( Parents can contact the CNB hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if you suspect or are worried that your children may be involved with drugs. Members of the public who have drug-related information can make a report to CNB by calling 1800-325-6666 or at

LATEST: 15-YEAR-OLD AMONG 92 SUSPECTS ARRESTED FOR DRUG OFFENCES In the latest island-wide operation conducted by CNB from 4 to 9 Apr, a total of about 129g of heroin, 49g of Ice, 2g of cannabis, 52g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 1g of ketamine, 17 Ecstasy tablets, 30 Erimin-5 tablets, and eight LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $15,000. A total of 92 suspected drug offenders were arrested, and the youngest arrested in this island-wide operation is a 15-year-old Singaporean female suspected drug abuser. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation include Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, Jurong and Punggol. Photo: Improvised lighters and heroin seized from a 43-year-old Singaporean females vehicle in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 4 on 5 April 2021. CNBOnTheMove

The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) Youth Forum is an annual event organised by the in the broader context of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs.This year, over 62 youth participants from around the world will gather virtually from 29 March to 2 April to learn more about different national drug control approaches, exchange views on how to better protect the health and well-being of their peers, and develop a joint statement to be delivered to global policy-makers.CNBs Anti-Drug Advocate Lim Zi Fei was selected to represent Singapore at the UNODC Youth Forum 2021.Participating in the UNODC Youth Forum is one of the greatest learning moments in my life. I am given the opportunity to connect and work with other youth participants from all over the world and contribute to the greater good of drug use prevention. - Lim Zi FeiIf you are passionate about the anti-drug cause and interested in such opportunities as well, join us as an Anti-Drug Advocate! The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $72,000. Thats right, black tar heroin is a thing. Its formed by a crude industrial process, making this version of heroin much more toxic, and putting you at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections. And no, smoking and snorting heroin is NOT any less harmful than any other methods of heroin abuse. Here are some other facts about heroin that you might not have known!DrugFreeSG

CNBOnTheMove: MORE THAN 35KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS SEIZED; DRUGS SUFFICIENT TO FEED MORE THAN 10,000 ABUSERS FOR A WEEK In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 16 and 17 Mar, three Singaporean males, aged between 27 and 33, were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. In total, over 35kg of illicit drugs were seized - including about 20.5kg of cannabis, 8.3kg of heroin, 6.4kg of Ice, about 1,091 Ecstasy tablets and 1,000 Erimin-5 tablets. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $1.7 million. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of drugs seized in the operation is sufficient to feed 3,950 heroin abusers, 3,700 Ice abusers and 2,930 cannabis abusers for a week. At CNB and the Home Team, we believe that drugs have no place in Singapore and we are committed to keep our streets safe from drugs.

Its Eat With Your Family Day today! DidYouKnowQuality family time builds stronger, connected families. Children who spend more quality time with their parents are less likely to get involved in risky behaviour and substance use. Studies link family dinners to increased resiliency and self-esteem in children, higher academic achievement, improved mental and physical health and even reduced risk of substance abuse and eating disorders. What are you eating with your family today? ListenFirst DrugFreeSG ParentingTips EWYFD2021

200 VIALS OF FENTANYL SEIZED, 3 ARRESTED BY CNBOn 1 March, ICA officers from Changi Airfreight Centre, Air Cargo Command noticed anomalies in the scanned images of a parcel declared as medicine from Vietnam. 200 vials believed to contain about 20mg of fentanyl were uncovered. Other illicit medicines were also found in the parcel. CNBOnTheMove: This detection prompted a follow-up operation by CNB officers, and the intended recipient of the parcel, a 30-year-old female Singapore Permanent Resident, was arrested in the vicinity of Beach Road. Two other Singaporean males (aged 62 and 25) were also arrested for suspected drug-related offences. The three suspects were escorted to their hideout, an apartment in the same vicinity. During a search of the apartment, other illicit medicines were found from within and HSA was alerted. Investigations into the drug activities of all the suspects are ongoing. DidYouKnow: Fentanyl is known to be a very potent opioid, approximately 50-100 times more potent than morphine. The abuse of fentanyl results in similar effects to other opioids, such as nausea, drowsiness, respiratory depression, low blood pressure and slow heart rate. Due to its potency, fentanyl abuse brings with it a heightened risk of death as a result of overdosing and there have been many cases in overseas jurisdictions of overdose deaths relating to fentanyl and its derivatives.CNB would like to remind the public that fentanyl and its derivatives are listed as Class A controlled drugs under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA). The possession, consumption, importation or trafficking of any controlled drug is an offence under the MDA.

2 MARCH DRAMA: 8 ARRESTED FOR SUSPECTED DRUG ACTIVITIES In the latest CNB operation on 2 March 2021, seven Singaporeans and one Malaysian (aged between 20 to 71) were arrested for suspected drug activities. A total of about 2kg of Ice, 928g of cannabis, 51g of heroin, 1g of cocaine, more than 4,000 Ecstasy tablets, and 106 Erimin-5 tablets were seized, along with cash amounting to $3,000. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth over $326,000. The arrests took place in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah and Sumang Walk. During the raid of a residential unit around Jalan Bukit Merah, one of suspects, a 32-year-old Malaysian male, attempted to evade arrest by scaling out of the window of the unit located on the second storey. In the process, he fell and suffered injuries. He was conveyed conscious to the Singapore General Hospital for medical attention. He is currently in stable condition. Investigations into the drug activities of all the suspects are ongoing. CNBOnTheMove

CNB officers were among the 26,218 Home Team frontliners who have received their first dose of the COVID-19 vaccination since the Home Team vaccination exercise started on 11 Jan 2021. Many of our officers have also received their second dose, and will be adequately protected against COVID-19 upon completing the full two-week vaccination regime.This is a strong testament to CNB's commitment in supporting the national fight against COVID-19. Being at the frontline to keep Singapore safe from the harms of drugs, it is important to protect ourselves against COVID-19 so that we can continue to carry out our duties effectively, and give our loved ones greater peace of mind when we are hard at work. SGUnited SGTogether DrugFreeSG

CNB conducted a virtual learning journey yesterday for Youth Advisory Group (YAG). At the session, we shared about the local drug situation and Singapores drug control approach, and gathered perspectives on the role that youths can play to advocate for a drug-free Singapore. Two of our Anti-Drug Advocates attended the session too! To find out how you can join youthvoices in advocating for a DrugFreeSG, do visit: DidYouKnow The YAG is a diverse group of youths appointed under the ambit of the National Committee on Prevention, Rehabilitation and Recidivism (NCPR). They provide youth perspectives to the work of the NCPR that is aimed at addressing issues such as juvenile delinquency (e.g. drug abuse).

CNBONTHEMOVE: MORE THAN 3KG OF HEROIN AND 3,000 ECSTASY TABLETS SEIZED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 25 and 26 Feb 2021, a total of 3,036g of heroin, 1,510g of 'Ice', 993g of cannabis, 7g of ketamine, more than 3,000 'Ecstasy' tablets and capsules, 15 Erimin-5 tablets, and a bottle of methadone were seized. Cash amounting to $47,879 was also recovered during the operation, which took place in multiple locations. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $480,000. In one of the cases, CNB officers arrested a 35-year-old Singaporean male for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Jalan Eunos. As the officers moved in to arrest the suspect, the 35-year-old male had put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to subdue him. A search was conducted on him, and a total of about 328g of heroin, 122g of 'Ice', 6g of ketamine, 93 'Ecstasy' tablets, 15 Erimin-5 tablets were seized, along with cash amounting to $18,900. A total of three Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug activities. Investigations are ongoing.Read the full story here:

In one of the cases, CNB officers arrested a 35-year-old Singaporean male for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Jalan Eunos. As the officers moved in to arrest the suspect, the 35-year-old male had put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to subdue him. A search was conducted on him, and a total of about 328g of heroin, 122g of 'Ice', 6g of ketamine, 93 'Ecstasy' tablets, 15 Erimin-5 tablets were seized, along with cash amounting to $18,900. A total of three Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug activities. Investigations are ongoing.Read the full story here:

CNBOnTheMove: 16-YEAR-OLD ARRESTED, AMONG 76 SUSPECTED DRUG OFFENDERS IN CNB ISLAND-WIDE OPERATIONIn an island-wide operation conducted by CNB from 21 to 26 Feb, an assortment of drugs including a total of about 866g of heroin, 588g of Ice, 568g of cannabis, 44g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), some ketamine, Ecstasy tablets, Erimin-5 tablets, and LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $135,000. The youngest arrested in this island-wide operation is a 16-year-old Singaporean female suspected drug abuser. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation include Ang Mo Kio, Bedok and Bukit Batok.Investigations are ongoing.

CNBONTHEMOVE: CLOSE TO 7.5KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS WORTH $0.4 MILLION SEIZEDIn the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 16 Feb 2021, a total of 3,720g of heroin, 2,934g of cannabis, 813g of 'Ice', and one Erimin-5 tablet were seized during the operation that took place in multiple locations in Singapore, along with cash amounting to $9,370. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $401,000. 2 Singaporeans and 1 Malaysian were arrested for suspected drug activities. In one of the cases, CNB officer raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Edgedale Plains. The occupant, a 24-year-old Singaporean male suspected drug offender, refused CNB officers entry into the unit and attempted to evade arrest by scaling out of the window of the unit located on the 17th storey. He was subsequently pulled to safety by CNB officers. A search was conducted in the unit, and a total of six packets containing about 776g of 'Ice' and two blocks weighing about 1,914g of cannabis were seized.Investigations are ongoing.

Happy Valentines Day! On this day as we celebrate love, DidYouKnow that science proves that being warm, loving and responsive are some of the most important actions parents can take to help their childrens development? Physical affection has health and developmental benefits that last throughout their childhood and adulthood. Valentines Day can be celebrated with your family too! What are you doing on this special day? ListenFirst DrugFreeSG ParentingTips

CNBONTHEMOVE: OVER 8KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS SEIZEDIn the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 2 and 3 Feb 2021, a total of about 5,217g of heroin, 2,226g of 'Ice' and 1,005g of cannabis were seized, along with cash amounting to $5,895. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $610,000. The total amount of heroin that had been seized in the operation is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,480 abusers for a week, while the total amount of 'Ice' seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 1,272 abusers for a week.3 Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug activities. Investigations are ongoing.

Investigations are ongoing.

Heres an overview of Singapores drug situation in 2020.In 2020, CNB has remained steadfast in its mission towards a DrugFreeSG, while also contributing to the national COVID-19 response. Close to 100 CNB officers were involved in contact-tracing, conducting checks on persons subject to Stay-Home Notice (SHN) orders and tracking down those who did not comply, as well as in the management of dormitory operations.While the local drug situation remained largely under control, the proportion of new abusers arrested and young abusers arrested remain significant. The international drug scene remains of concern too. There is a strong push by parties with vested interests for more liberal drug policies. Global methamphetamine seizures reached a record high, and there are indications of increased trafficking in Southeast Asia. Methamphetamine has been the most commonly abused drug in Singapore since 2015. The Singapore drug control strategy is a comprehensive one that tackles both drug supply and demand through preventive drug education (PDE), tough anti-drug laws, vigorous enforcement, and effective rehabilitation and aftercare. Despite challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, CNB conducted intensive enforcement operations dismantling 24 drug syndicates, and together with various Home Team agencies, conducted over 500 operations to intercept drugs entering Singapore. COVID-19 did not put a stop to CNBs PDE efforts as the first line of defence against drugs as well. CNB continued with our outreach by taking community engagement events, and PDE talks online, as well as offering the live-streaming of PDE skits to schools. Drug abuse exacts a high cost on abusers, their families, and ultimately society. Livelihoods are lost, relationships are destroyed, children suffer and the wider community too, because of drug-related crimes. Singapore hence adopts a harm-prevention approach to drugs, aimed at preventing the harms that drugs bring to individuals, families and society. CNB stands together with the community, and will continue to keep Singapore drug-free for our future generations.

Hey parents, your child would have received their Little Red Dot publication in school this week! This months edition features a comic-strip story that educates primary school students on how to say no to drugs. There's also a fun contest within that you can do with your child and stand to win a limited-edition DrugFreeSG goodie bag! If you prefer an e-copy, you may download it here: DrugFreeSG

Check out this month's edition of IN Magazine (distributed to secondary school students), which features an inspiring comic-strip story about the diary of an Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA). There's also a fun contest within that you can complete, where upon completion youll stand to win a limited-edition DrugFreeSG goodie bag! Download the e-copy here: DrugFreeSG

What are New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), and are they really new?Whether theyre called designer drugs or herbal highs, these substances arent new, nor are they as fancy as they sound.Lets clear the air on what they are, and how dangerous they can be.DrugFreeSG

CNBONTHEMOVE: OVER 3KG OF HEROIN SEIZEDIn the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 28 Jan 2021, a total of about 3,055g of heroin, 58g of 'Ice', and one 'Ecstasy' fragment were seized. Cash amounting to $1,650 and 100 nitrazepam tablets, a substance listed under the Poisons Act, were also recovered during the operation. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth over $220,000.Two suspected drug offenders were arrested. As the officers moved in to arrest the suspects, both had put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to subdue them. Investigations are ongoing.

CNBOnTheMove: OVER 1KG OF HEROIN AND CANNABIS SEIZED; 4 ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 19 Jan, an assortment of drugs including about 1.4kg of heroin, 1kg of cannabis, 135g of Ice and some Erimin-5 and Ecstasy tablets worth close to $141,000 were seized. Four suspects were arrested. Forced entry was effected in a residential unit in the vicinity of Telok Blangah Drive, as the occupants had refused to heed the lawful orders of the CNB officers to open the door. Four Singaporean males, aged 49, 51, 56 and 61, were arrested therein. A search was conducted, and a total of ten packets and bundles containing about 1,487g of heroin, 15 packets containing about 135g of Ice, a bundle containing about 1,048g of cannabis, 10 Ecstasy tablets and 109 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered from various locations within and in the vicinity of the unit. Investigations are ongoing.

89 SUSPECTED DRUG OFFENDERS ARRESTED IN CNB ISLAND-WIDE OPERATION ; SUSPECTED DRUG OFFENDERS' 5 AND 6-YEAR-OLD CHILDREN PRESENT DURING ARREST CNBOnTheMoveIn the latest island-wide operation by CNB, a total of 89 suspected drug offenders were arrested, and a total of about 608g of heroin, 113g of 'Ice', 109g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 25g of cannabis, 11 Erimin-5 tablets, 8 'Ecstasy' tablet and 2 bottles of methadone were seized. Various drug paraphernalia and offensive weapons were also recovered. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $15,000.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Tampines Street 21 and arrested a Singaporean couple. During the raid, the couple's children, a 5-year-old and 6-year-old, were also present in the unit. Preliminary investigations showed that the couple would abuse drugs together in their home and had last abused drugs the night before their arrest. The children were subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.In another case, CNB officers arrested a 22-year-old Singaporean female in the vicinity of Merpati Road, where a packet containing about 0.3g of 'Ice' found concealed in a wireless earphone casing was recovered from her. Investigations are ongoing.

New Psychoactive Substances, or NPS for short, are classified as drugs that mimic the same highs that other drugs such as cocaine, meth, cannabis, or ecstasy produce. But what makes them so dangerous if they are just imitations? Stay tuned as we tackle the wanna-be drug and show just how dangerous they can be.DrugFreeSG

My life while I was on drugs was one of darkness I felt hopeless with no way out. My relationship with my family deteriorated and I found it almost impossible to be or do anything good. But things are different now!Being able to pick up a skill of interest learning culinary arts at HCSA Academy, has set a direction and vision for my life. It has given me the ability to work and provide for my family while living a drug-free life, something I find very important but could never do in the past. Aloysius Wee, Graduate of HCSA Academy SingaporeansAgainstDrugs DrugFreeSG

A career that makes a difference - When officers join CNB, they can expect an exciting and meaningful career. It is a job that requires our officers to put in long and irregular hours. They need to have the courage to deal with drug offenders, as well as the compassion to help individuals and families who have been affected by drugs. For those who heed this calling, it is a rewarding career. There is a sense of purpose and an everyday satisfaction knowing that you are helping to keep Singapore drug-free.Find out how you can apply for a scholarship and a meaningful career at CNB here: DrugFreeSG: Be Part Of It

(3) CNBONTHEMOVE LATEST ISLAND-WIDE OPERATION (23 TO 27 NOV): SUSPECT HID IN STOREROOM BEHIND FALSE WALL IN AN ATTEMPT TO EVADE ARRESTIn another operation on 26 Nov, CNB officers raided a flat in the vicinity of Edgefield Plains, and arrested a 25-year-old Singaporean male and 24-year-old Singaporean female. A total of 32 packets containing about 631g of Ice, 3 packets containing about 113g of cannabis, and 16 Ecstasy tablets were seized. Cash amounting to $25,393 was also recovered from the unit.During the raid, CNB officers detected a storeroom behind a false wall. Officers moved in swiftly and arrested the 25-year-old Singaporean male who was hiding in the storeroom. The 25-year-old male had put up a struggle to resist arrest, and necessary force was used to subdue him.Investigations are ongoing.

(2) CNBONTHEMOVE LATEST ISLAND-WIDE OPERATION (23 TO 27 NOV): TWO MOTHERS, AGED 19 AND 26, WERE USING DRUGS IN FRONT OF THEIR FIVE-YEAR-OLD AND FOUR-MONTH-OLD CHILDREN In another case on 23 Nov, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Lengkok Bahru, and arrested three suspects a 29-year-old Singaporean male, a 26-year-old Singaporean male and a 19-year-old Singaporean female. A 26-year-old Singaporean female who later returned to the same unit was also promptly arrested for suspected drug activities. A total of six packets containing about 3g of Ice were recovered in the unit, while drug paraphernalia were found on the 26-year-old Singaporean female.The 5-year-old son of the 26-year-old female, and the 4-month-old son of the 19-year-old female were also present during the arrest. Preliminary investigations showed that the 19-year-old female had brought her 4-month-old infant to visit the unit, and later abused drugs along with the 29-year-old male and 26-year-old male in the unit. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of both children were taken care of. Both children were subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Investigations are ongoing.

(1) CNBONTHEMOVE LATEST ISLAND-WIDE OPERATION (23 TO 27 NOV): DRUGS FOUND CONCEALED IN SKINCARE PRODUCT PACKAGING From 23 to 27 Nov, a total of 87 suspects were arrested in an island-wide operation conducted by CNB.In one of the cases on 23 Nov, CNB officers arrested a 39-year-old Singaporean male in the vicinity of Sumang Lane. 15 packets containing about 339g of Ice, seven Ecstasy tablets, and 90 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered from the suspects residential unit. Five bottles and a packet containing liquid believed to be liquid methamphetamine concealed in skincare product packaging were also seized from the unit, along with various drug paraphernalia. Investigations are ongoing. In the island-wide operation, a total of over 1.1KG of Ice, 1.4KG of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 764g of heroin, and other drugs including cannabis, ketamine, Ecstasy tablets, Erimin-5 tablets, LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, and five bottles and a packet containing liquid believed to be liquid methamphetamine were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $400,000.Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation include Boon Lay, Buangkok and Aljunied.

Youve probably heard that methamphetamine meth isnt good for you. But, do you know why we shouldnt meth around with this dangerous drug? When you consume meth, it floods your body with dopamine for a temporary 'high'. Then you will crave for more and more 'highs', which quickly messes up your brain and body - often irreversibly. DrugFreeSG

CNBONTHEMOVE: OVER 1KG OF ICE SEIZED, 5 ARRESTED On 16 and 17 Nov, CNB officers seized over 1.3KG of Ice, and a large assortment of drugs including cannabis, ketamine, Ecstasy tablets and fragments, Erimin-5 tablets, Yaba tablets, LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps and liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate). Cash amounting to $18,250, and weapons such as a Karambit knife, watermelon knives, parang knife and baseball bat were also recovered during the operation, which took place at multiple locations in the vicinity of Somme Road, Yishun Ring Road and Balestier Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $410,000. Five suspects were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of 1,314g of Ice seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 750 abusers for a week.

CNBONTHEMOVE: 14KG HEROIN SEIZED, 5 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 11 Nov, a total of about 14.1KG of heroin, 7.5KG of cannabis, 2.8KG of Ice, 1,008 Erimin-5 tablets, and some Ecstasy fragments and Ecstasy tablets were seized. Cash amounting to $12,629 was also seized from the operation that took place in multiple locations - including the vicinity of Siglap Road and Bedok Reservoir Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $2 million. Five suspects, comprising three men and two women aged between 29 and 55 were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of drugs seized in the operation is sufficient to feed 6,740 heroin abusers for a week, 1,630 Ice abusers for a week and 1,080 cannabis abusers for a week. Drug traffickers take huge gambles by exploiting and capitalising on addiction and the misery that drug abuse brings to the family. CNB has been keeping a close watch on the drug situation and will not let up on our enforcement efforts. CNB is committed to keeping the streets of Singapore safe from drugs, and would like to remind the public that the consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs is an offence under the Misuse of Drugs Act. Singapore has strict laws for drug trafficking and CNB will continue to mount regular, sustained operations against drug traffickers and abusers alike, to keep the streets of Singapore drug-free.

CNBONTHEMOVE: 14KG HEROIN SEIZED, 5 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 11 Nov, a total of about 14.1KG of heroin, 7.5KG of cannabis, 2.8KG of Ice, 1,008 Erimin-5 tablets, and some Ecstasy fragments and Ecstasy tablets were seized. Cash amounting to $12,629 was also seized from the operation that took place in multiple locations - including the vicinity of Siglap Road and Bedok Reservoir Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $2 million. Five suspects, comprising three men and two women aged between 29 and 55 were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of drugs seized in the operation is sufficient to feed 6,740 heroin abusers for a week, 1,630 Ice abusers for a week and 1,080 cannabis abusers for a week. Drug traffickers take huge gambles by exploiting and capitalising on addiction and the misery that drug abuse brings to the family. CNB has been keeping a close watch on the drug situation and will not let up on our enforcement efforts. CNB is committed to keeping the streets of Singapore safe from drugs, and would like to remind the public that the consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs is an offence under the Misuse of Drugs Act. Singapore has strict laws for drug trafficking and CNB will continue to mount regular, sustained operations against drug traffickers and abusers alike, to keep the streets of Singapore drug-free.

CNBOnTheMove: 168 DRUG OFFENDERS ARRESTED IN CNB 2-WEEK ISLAND-WIDE OPERATIONA total of 168 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide operation from 5 to 16 Oct 2020. In this two-week island-wide operation, a total of about 561g of cannabis, about 433g of 'Ice', about 303g of heroin, about 61g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), about 1g of ketamine, 19 'Ecstasy' tablets, 19 Erimin-5 tablets, 12 bottles of cannabis vape cartridges, eight bottles of black liquid believed to contain opium, and one bottle of liquid believed to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $163,000. In one of the cases, the 3-year-old daughter of a 31-year-old Singaporean female, who was arrested for suspected drug activities, was present in the unit during the raid. Arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the 3-year-old girl was taken care of. The girl was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Investigations are ongoing.Read the full story here:

CNBOnTheMove: LARGE ASSORTMENT OF DRUGS INCLUDING 3.6KG OF ICE SEIZED, 11 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 7 and 8 Oct, eleven suspected drug offenders were arrested at multiple locations in Singapore - including Jalan Selamat, Lorong Limau, Tampines, Aljunied Crescent and Upper Weld Road. A large assortment of drugs including 3.6kg of Ice, nearly 1kg of cannabis, 265g of heroin, some ketamine, Ecstasy tablets and Erimin-5 tablets worth about $1.2million were seized. Cash amounting to $15,784 was also recovered during the operation. In one of the cases, more than 1kg of Ice and about 398g of ketamine were recovered from a bicycle in the vicinity of Aljunied Crescent.Investigations into the drug activities of all the suspects are ongoing. The total amount of 3,651g of Ice seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,100 abusers for a week.

NEVER A NEED FOR SPEED: $160,000 WORTH OF ICE AND HEROIN SEIZED IN VEHICLE INTERCEPTED BY CNB OFFICERS CNBOnTheMove In the evening of 2 Oct, CNB officers intercepted a vehicle in the vicinity of Netheravon Road, and arrested a 56-year-old Singaporean male. A search of the vehicle was conducted, and two bundles containing about 527g of Ice and two packets containing about 18g of heroin were recovered. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth $160,000. Prior to the arrest, a 38-year-old Malaysian male was believed to have left a package in the vicinity of Changi Coast Road, which was then collected by the 56-year-old Singaporean. The 38-year-old Malaysian male was later arrested in the vicinity of Nicoll Drive. In a series of follow-up operations, CNB officers arrested one other Singaporean male and one Malaysian male at various locations, for suspected drug activities.527g of Ice is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 300 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.

I LIVE TO MOTIVATE OTHERSAdjusting to the new normal in 2020 was hard for me. In less than a year we went from no restrictions, to the circuit breaker measures, to working from home and now to partial opening.A lot of changes had happened in such a short time, and these had affected people. I think everyone, including myself is struggling to a certain degree. However, I accepted what came my way and made plans accordingly. I was also more mindful, and aware of burn-out signs. I acknowledged them and consciously adjusted my responses to make myself and others feel better.MIND SO was born in the end of 2019, during the 3 months when I was jobless (or what I prefer to call fun-employed). It was then that I started to shift my focus towards the basic aspects of my life. Working out, eating healthy, reading books and taking care of my mental well-being have become fundamental to my daily life. Surprisingly, more inspiration came to me and I had the urge to share that with others too. I have always believed that ones mindset changes everything, I consider it a blessing if others find what I share valuable and has a positive impact on their lives. I believe it is important to have someone or something important to ground you in life. For me, it was my family, friends and myself. To find purpose and meaning in life, we need to ask why we are living. For a start, we can try to appreciate the little moments in life that make us feel good and valued. Once you start doing that, I believe the Aha! moment will come to you soon.29-year-old Danling is part of a business development team in a tech firm. In her free time, she manages MIND SO () a page on Instagram featuring motivational quotes, images and podcasts. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

122 PACKETS OF HEROIN (858g) AND 71 PACKETS OF ICE (133g) SEIZED IN RAID ON HOTEL ROOMS NEAR BEACH RD; SUSPECTED TRAFFICKER OPENLY DISPLAYED DRUGS TO 12-YEAR-OLD SON CNBOnTheMoveIn the latest two-week island-wide operation by CNB, a total of 162 suspected drug offenders were arrested, and an assortment of drugs including about 870g of heroin, 586g of Ice, some Ecstasy tablets, Erimin-5 tablets, ketamine, New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) and GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) estimated to be worth about $260,500 were seized. The youngest arrested is a 14-year-old suspected drug abuser.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided two hotel rooms in the vicinity of Beach Road, and arrested five Singaporeans. Drugs including 122 packets containing about 858g of heroin and 71 packets containing about 133g of Ice were recovered from two rooms in the hotel. A Karambit knife was also seized in one of the rooms, along with various drug paraphernalia.During the raid, it was found that a 35-year-old male suspected drug trafficker had his 12-year-old son with him, and the drugs displayed openly in front of his son in the room. The boy's mother, a 36-year-old, was also arrested during the raid for suspected drug offences. The boy was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin. Investigations are ongoing.

I LIVE FOR MY ARTMy biggest regret to date was that I allowed drugs to destroy my life, my health, my freedom and my relationship with my loved ones. Worst of all, it robbed me of my dignity. While I was still incarcerated, my dad passed away and I was unable to bid him farewell nor be by his side as he left the world. That was my lowest point in life. I would say the most difficult thing I had to do was to overcome that dark moment, stay focused on my own recovery and not allow my past to bound me or turn into self-pity. During that period, my passion for art and the people who cared and rendered assistance to me kept me grounded. I was given the opportunity to attend art classes while I was still in prison. Since then, I have ventured into different forms of art, including painting, sculpturing, pottery and batik. This artistic discovery prompted me to view the world differently. It opened my eyes to view things from many perspectives and to stay optimistic. I once had a dream where I was on the front page of the newspapers with the headline, From Syringe to Brush. That dream sparked a hope for my existence and passion. By expressing myself through art, I found a new lease of life one that is far from my past struggle with substance abuse. Today I am living my dream as a full-time artist with my own studio and gallery.53-year-old Barry Yeow is a full-time artist, Yellow Ribbon Mentor and the owner of 5seventeen art gallery in Singapore. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

CNBOnTheMove: FIVE ARRESTED FOR SUSPECTED DRUG OFFENCES, INCLUDING MAN INVOLVED IN CANBERRA STREET CAR CHASE AND A WOMAN WHO ABUSED ICE DURING PREGNANCY On 16 Sep, CNB arrested a 29-year-old Singaporean, who was the passenger in the car chase along Canberra Street on 12 Sep, for suspected drug trafficking offences. Four other Singaporeans were also arrested during the operation that took place in multiple locations in Singapore. A total of about 7g of Ice was seized. Among those arrested was a 31-year-old female. Preliminary investigations revealed that she had been abusing Ice during her pregnancy. She was with her 4-month-old infant at the time of arrest. The infant was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a relative. Investigations are ongoing.

I LIVE FOR GIVING BACK TO OTHERS After my National Service, curiosity got the better of me and I started getting involved in drugs. This dragged on for more than 20 years. Not only did it affect my future, it also affected my relationship with my family. There were many incidents over the course of the years where I struggled and was tempted to turn back to drugs. However, the HCSA Highpoint community has really kept me and my fellow brothers grounded by constantly keeping in touch with us.I believe everyone should set goals for what they want to achieve in their life, regardless of who they are. These goals will keep them going and remind them of what they are fighting for. For me, I hope to contribute meaningfully to society, and I want to upgrade myself and seize any opportunities that come my way.Currently, I am journeying with a few at-risk youths from disadvantaged families to help them stay on the right track and to steer clear from the dangers of drugs. Being free from drugs is one of my lifes greatest achievements and I hope to be a role model who advocates against drug abuse.49-year-old Zulkifli is an alumnus of , where he resided in after his release from prison in 2017.What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

I LIVE FOR MUAY THAII wouldn't say my childhood was easy for my brother and I, but as a single parent, my mother did her best to provide us with everything, many a times leaving her without much for herself. Still, she always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I was introduced to violence as I used to get bullied in school. As the years went by, I started becoming more aggressive. I picked up Muay Thai to protect myself from bullies, and I quickly realised I was good at it. However, I used my talent in the wrong way and got into trouble with the law at a young age. This delinquent cycle continued until I was 21 years old.When I went back to Muay Thai again, I was fortunate to be given the right motivation and help from my trainers and employers who helped me make something out of myself.Now I want to give people that same chance and if I could save them from wasting their youth like I did, it would be very meaningful to me. Muay Thai is what keeps me from going back to my old delinquent ways.I believe everyone needs something in their life to live for as it helps motivate people to get them going. For me it was Muay Thai. Having more motivated people makes our society a better place to live in.25-year-old Alvin Sham Raaj, is a professional Muay Thai fighter and a trainer. He is currently working his way towards starting up his own gym where he can give others the same fighting chance he had. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

1.5KG OF HEROIN, 1.2KG OF ICE AND OTHER DRUGS WORTH MORE THAN HALF A MILLION DOLLARS SEIZED IN LATEST CNB DRUG BUST On 8 Sep, CNB officers seized a large assortment of drugs - including about 1.5kg of heroin, about 1.2kg of Ice, 7,502 Erimin-5 tablets, 669 Ecstasy tablets, 512g of ketamine and 10g of cannabis. Cash amounting to $8,680 was also recovered. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $640,000. Two Singaporean suspects - a 30-year-old male and 28-year-old female, were arrested. A search by CNB officers of the 30-year-old male suspects residential unit recovered up to 24 packets and bottles of Ice and other drugs, along with packaging materials. A subsequent search of his vehicle recovered three bundles of heroin. Investigations are ongoing. CNBOnTheMove

Cash amounting to $8,680 was also recovered. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $640,000. Two Singaporean suspects - a 30-year-old male and 28-year-old female, were arrested. A search by CNB officers of the 30-year-old male suspects residential unit recovered up to 24 packets and bottles of Ice and other drugs, along with packaging materials. A subsequent search of his vehicle recovered three bundles of heroin. Investigations are ongoing. CNBOnTheMove

LIVE FOR YOURSELF, LIVE FOR YOUR DREAMSGrowing up, I was hard on myself and I blamed myself for a lot of things. It made me insecure about every decision I made. There was a time when I felt lost, I had no direction in life, and I felt like there was nothing to live for. I was just not able to see beauty in the things around me anymore. I hope no one ever feels that way.Thankfully, my sister was around to motivate me. From there, I decided to live for my dream of helping others and my family. I think we all need something to keep us motivated and something to live for. If we have that one thing to keep us going, life starts to make more sense! I hope people can continue to live for themselves and know that theyre needed as well. We never really know whos struggling and I think its important to always be kind or give a little encouragement to help motivate someone. As long as Im healthy and able to give a helping hand, I want to do the best I can to help someone get back up on their feet again.Previously a nurse, and currently working full time at Childrens Aid Society, 27-year-old Anisahs role is to provide guidance in supporting residents growth and development. Additionally, she also acts as a role model to them and attempts to instil good attitudes and values. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

EXPOSED: CNB raid at two Sentosa hotel rooms uncovers assortment of drugs, $25,950 in cashOn 31 Aug, CNB officers conducted raids at multiple locations in Singapore, including at Sentosa, Simei and Anchorvale.An assortment of drugs - including a total of 622g of cannabis, some ketamine, Ecstasy tablets, Erimin-5 tablets and 4 pieces of LSD (lysergide) were seized. Five suspects were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. CNBOnTheMove

CNBOnTheMove: $230,000 WORTH OF DRUGS SEIZED; FIVE ARRESTED On 27 Aug, CNB officers intercepted a car in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 5 and seized about 550g of Ice from within the vehicle. Two suspects were arrested. A subsequent search of one of the suspects residence saw the seizure of about 291g of heroin and a bundle containing around 1kg of cannabis. In a follow-up operation in the vicinity of Bukit Panjang Ring Road, CNB officers recovered another 1kg of cannabis and arrested two suspects. Prior to the arrest, one of the suspects was believed to have discarded a package containing about 965g of cannabis out of a residential units window. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth $230,000 in total. Investigations are ongoing.

Happy International Day of Families!DidYouKnow As part of Singapore's anti-drug strategy, our rehabilitation programme also offers family support and family programmes to help drug offenders pick up skills to strengthen family bonds. This may include joint family sessions to tackle issues such as the impact of addiction on the rest of the family.Familial and community support play a big part towards a DrugFreeSG

Thats right, this is the myth! Potacin de guaya, a wine or brandy in which marijuana buds have been steeped, actually translates to the drink of grief. From this, it was shortened to pot.Read through some of the interesting facts about weed that you might not have known. DrugFreeSG

We are proud of CNB Investigation Officers SI Yew Kok Hong and SSSGT Rochelle Chia who were deployed to support MOM as part of the national response to COVID-19. Our officers applied their investigative and fieldwork expertise as they worked alongside MOM Enforcement Officers to ensure that foreign work pass holders on Leave of Absence and Stay-Home Notice comply with the orders, and that their well-being is looked after by their employers. Check out our IG stories for the full interview! SGUnited CNB247

Tuesday ICYMI Remember the students from who developed the AR mobile application game Seal No To Drugs? Their project was recently selected for the Indie Prize China 2019 showcase (organised by Game Daily Connect)! Held in Shenzhen, China from 10 12 November, the Indie Prize is a global competition featuring the most creative, independent projects of the gaming industry. Seal No To Drugs offers players an immersive gameplay experience, while learning about the dangers of drugs. Players will encounter different types of drugs throughout the game, and the characters in the game will experience the negative effects of drug abuse such as hallucinations and loss of co-ordination. Check out Seal No To Drugs on the Apple or Google Play Store today! DrugFreeSG

Planting a Seed of Hope at The Green Haven Halfway House TuesdayOur Anti-Drug Advocates (ADA) enjoyed a hands-on horticulture experience at the Green Haven Halfway House, learnt the ropes on important advocacy skills, and got a better understanding of Singapores drug rehabilitation framework during CNBs ADA engagement session in September DidYouKnow:The Green Haven Halfway House adopted the Therapeutic Horticulture approach to improve residents overall holistic health and sense of well-being. Through the Plant a Seed of Hope activity, individuals cultivate patience and develop a sense of satisfaction and empowerment as they nurture the seedling into a mature plant. If you are interested in joining future sessions, or learning more about the ADA programme, do visit the link in bio for more details! DrugFreeSG AntiDrugAdvocates

Cannabis: Facts and Myths A mini-series [Part 1]Cannabis cures cancer, is a harmless plant and is good for you? Here are some studies on the impact of cannabis legalisation from some parts of the world. MYTH 1: LEGALISATION WILL KEEP YOUTHS AWAY FROM CANNABIS.FALSE. According to the latest findings from the 2018 National Survey on Drug Use and Health in United States, the proportion of the population that used cannabis in 2018 was the highest since 2002. Cannabis use has been proven harmful, especially to children. Legalising it only makes things worse.

My mother has always been my role model and best friend. From an early age, she has inspired and motivated me to continuously grow as a person to give back to society and impact lives through meaningful ways. With that, I joined the Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) programme with .DrugFreeSG, as Im extremely passionate about the anti-drug cause and keen to influence my peers to keep Singapore drug-free! As an ADA, Id assisted with and implemented several anti-drug initiatives, such as the YourLifeisInYourHands initiative. I was also honoured to represent Singapore at the annual UN Office on Drugs and Crime Youth Forum 2019, which was held in Vienna, Austria. All these were made possible with my moms unwavering support and her trust in me. At times when things arent going well for me, shes always there for me. Im extremely thankful for her and blessed to have her full support in the things that I do!-Javier Ng, Anti-Drug AdvocateOurSingapore NDP2019 DrugFreeSG

Dudu (pacifiers) vs Du (drugs/) All mothers will know what pacifiers (dudus in colloquial Mandarin) are, regardless of whether their children have actually used them. While there are differing opinions concerning the use of pacifiers, we know why they exist for many babies they provide temporary comfort, help them fall asleep and keep them happy all day, every day. And perhaps some babies keep using them for a little too long However, no mother would approve of her children getting involved in the other Du (drugs in Mandarin). We know drugs are much harder to quit. In some cases, the precious lives that your mothers gave you are needlessly squandered away. Dont break your mothers heart this Mothers Day. Stay away from drugs. - Joyce, once a Dudu (not a Du) addict, now a FTWM SingaporeansAgainstDrugs DrugFreeSG MothersDay2019 HappyMothersDay celebratingmotherhood

Our participants had a great time at the videography workshop today! We invited two accomplished filmmakers, and , to share some useful tips on video production in light of the upcoming DrugFreeSG Video Competition.Hear what our workshop participant Jing En has to say: 'I want to spread anti-drug awareness in my school so that people understand that drugs are harmful and it affects your family as well. This workshop is a good experience for me as I do not have many opportunities in school to learn about filmmaking in great detail. This workshop also taught me how to produce a good story.' We're looking forward to their ideas!

Drug abuse is harmless fun? Let's examine the facts.Sources: A Literature Review on Medical Cannabis, conducted in 2015, by a team of psychiatrists and researchers from the Institute of Mental Health, Singapore: Dr Jimmy Lee, Dr Christopher Cheok, Dr Gomathinayagam Kandasami, Dr Attilio Rapisarda, Dr Ho New Fei; United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, World Drug Campaign Website; Central Narcotics Bureau WebsiteDrugFreeSG

As CNB officers, we do not only enforce, we also engage and educate. We communicate with our supervisees to understand their concerns, look out for their well-being, educate them, and help them to lead a drug-free life. As a supervision officer, Larry goes beyond overseeing supervisees reporting for urine tests. At the end of the day, he gets his job satisfaction from knowing hes playing his part to help those whove had a brush with drugs to stay clean and get back on their feet. CNB247 DrugFreeSG

Latest: About 3.5kg of Cannabis, 2.94kg of Heroin, and an assortment of Ice, Erimin-5 tablets, and Ecstasy tablets were seized in an operation conducted by the CNB in the evening of 20 Nov 2018. Worth over S$305,000, the drugs seized were enough to feed the addiction of about 1,900 abusers for a week. Investigations into the drug activities of the three arrested suspects are ongoing.CNBonthemove

ICYMI On 26 June 2018, we held the DrugFreeSG Light-up event at the Marina Bay area. To commemorate the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking, we worked with our partners to light up the Marina Bay and Harbourfront (Sentosa) area in green and white the colours represented by our Anti-Drug Ribbon which symbolise Health, Vitality and Strength. Thank you for all the support and we hope you had fun!

Yesterday, a 27-year-old male foreign national was arrested when he was entering Singapore. He was wanted for an earlier case of forgery for the purpose of cheating. A search of his luggage found a total of about 3kg of Cannabis and 4,831 Yaba tablets. The Cannabis were hidden within canisters and boxes labelled as containing food items. The Yaba tablets and fragments were found hidden within a handphone box. Follow-up investigations by CNB led to the arrest of the suspected intended recipient of the drugs found in the luggage. Investigations are ongoing.

Last night, CNB conducted two separate operations and more than S$197,000 worth of drugs were seized. 7 suspected drug offenders were arrested during the operations. In one of the cases, it was believed that the drug offenders booked a room at a hotel in the vicinity of Raffles Boulevard. CNB officers raided the hotel room and arrested two Singaporean male suspects and one female foreign national. Both male suspects put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to restrain them. A total of about 1,456g of heroin, 1,000g of cannabis, 10g of ice and cash amounting to S$6,250 were recovered from within the room. Investigations into the drug activities of all suspects are ongoing.

The VR simulation project Paranoia, developed by School of Interactive and Digital Media students in support of the anti-drug message, has been selected as one of the Top 3 entries from the Singapore leg of the MYouth Mobile App Challenge! Here are some photos of the team attending the Asian MYouth hack camp in Hong Kong with other young developers and social change-makers. The VR simulation, developed by students Leong Jun Xiang, Zheng Qing Ping, Teo Zhe Kai and Naseer Ismail, recreates the hallucinations, sense of paranoia, as well as loss of balance and co-ordination that drug abusers experience, to reiterate the negative effects of drug abuse. Congrats to the team, and thank you for supporting a DrugFreeSG!

A collection of heart-warming stories of ten inspiring fathers. Mr Mohamed Nor Ismail one of the fathers featured in this book - opens up about his chequered past with drug addiction, and the negative consequences he had to bear. His story is one that shows how rehabilitation and familial support can help conquer drug addiction. This Fathers Day, spend some time with your loved ones, and remember that the greatest gift you can give your father is to lead a life with no regrets. DrugFreeSG HappyFathersDay

We collaborated with Assumption Pathway School (APS) to develop a customised anti-drug decal and here we have the winning design!The vibrant colors of the border portrays Singapores racial and religious diversity. Despite the multi-cultural, multi-racial and multi-religion background, people are living in peace and harmony. The inclusion of the iconic Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Changi Airport and Merlion symbolises the distinctiveness and identity of Singapore. As for the text, red font was used to emphasise the word FREE so as to capture viewers attention. Conversely, grey was used on the word DRUG so as to give a dilute, blurry image and to show it fading away (disappearing). The message that the student wants to convey is that he hoped that drugs will disappear in Singapore eventually and Singapore will become a country that is free from drugs where everyone can live and play in a Drug-Free Zone.

Besides her passion for the anti-drug cause, also enjoys drawing. Today was another proud moment for her in Vienna. The UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) selected this artwork of hers, and presented it to the Head of Mission, Ambassador Prof. Dr. Gnther A. Granser of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta today.Afikah has a story behind this drawing: I hope to be like a feather, so light and free. Not bound by anything, so I can be what I choose to be. May the wind one day lift me, together with my hopes and dreams.

[Register NOW!] There are LIMITED seats available. So do sign up for the workshop soon! (Link in bio)Filmmaker, Ric Aw who will be hosting the Workshop has provided a sneak preview of what to expect: 1. What can we expect to gain from the workshop? We hope to share with you the basic principles of filmmaking. You can expect a highly condensed half-day session that covers storytelling, production and simple technical tips on film making. Once you get the foundation right, the rest of the learning builds on that. 2. Where do you get the inspirations for your short films and feature films? Our daily encounters in life provide lots of inspirations for stories. I am always on the look-out for interesting news, events, novels, stories that I hear from friends. Even stories that inspire a piece of artwork could become the big idea behind my films. I think having a curious mind helps as well. Most importantly, once I have my heart set on an idea, I will focus my energy to translate the idea into a film for sharing with the masses. 3. What advice do you have for aspiring filmmakers? Do not be afraid to realise your own ideas. Your idea is unique because it came from you. It is your voice that makes your story special and no one can mimic your film language.

My mother taught me how to use heroin, I smoke it using the chase the dragon method. Being a father myself, I wonder why any parent will introduce their child to drugs. The instinct to protect is lost as they cede control to the drugs. As an officer, the above statement made me even more determined to prevent others from falling to the harms of drugs." - Lim Wee Beng, Head InvestigationSingaporeansAgainstDrugs

CNB247 18:30hrs Being a CNB Investigation Officer is a demanding job. But there is no greater sense of satisfaction like the one I get from piecing together evidence, uncovering the truth and seeing justice done. InvestigationOfficer

CNB247 12:05hrsIn our line of work, we sometimes struggle between compassion and justice. Investigators are humans too and we do feel for the accused and their family members at times. But we need to be objective and not be clouded by all these emotions. Thus, we are trained to rely on evidence and taught not to make judgments during the course of investigation. The role and responsibilities of an investigator are critical. As a law enforcement officer, its our duty and honour to remain impartial in upholding the law and order.
CNB247 14:50hrsThis is the Old Supreme Court Building. .Buildings may change, but our conviction remains. OldSupremeCourt

CNB247 11:24hrs Physical evidence cannot be intimidated. It does not forget. It sits there and waits to be detected, preserved, evaluated and explained. The Evidence Never Lies, 1984InvestigationOfficer

CNB247 16:01hrsOur close partner. They are the ones who help us verify and analyse the exhibits seized.CNBxHSA DNALab

Hi, this is Luke. Ive been given the opportunity to take over CNBs Instagram account. For the next few weeks, I will be showing yall more about the life of a CNB Investigation Officer. CNB247 InvestigationOfficer

I made a strong commitment to shun and keep away from drugs after learning of many examples of families and relationships being broken and destroyed. While studying in the US, I observed many destitute adults as a result of drug consumption and it was a warning for me to stay far away from drugs. The outcome is neither something I can deal with nor put my loved ones through. - Gabriel Lam - COO, Shalom International Movers Pte LtdSingaporeansAgainstDrugs
"Wheels and spills, no pills!" - Emiline Chee, Motor Sales Executive at Harley Davidson.SingaporeansAgainstDrugs

"I choose to be drug-free because there are many other addictions in life. For me, I am addicted to adventure, and it's better to be an adventure junkie than a druggie because at least you remember the adrenaline that you've been through." - Sharan, 34, Senior Global Marketing Manager.SingaporeansAgainstDrugs

"I don't like the idea of being bound and strangled by an addiction. It's also too naive to think that we must try everything once, and we must always ask ourselves if we can bear the consequences or if we will regret the action. For me, drugs is a no-go. I already don't enjoy taking medication, what more drugs and causing self-harm." - Alvin Wong, Student.SingaporeansAgainstDrugs

"I never thought that one day I would end up working in CNB. When I was in my final year in poly, I went for a career fair with my friend and we happened to pass by the MHA booth. I sent in my application to CNB as I find the job quite meaningful. We get to contribute for a drug-free Singapore so that we all have a safe place to live in." - Wei Ting, CNB Enforcement Officer. SingaporeansAgainstDrugs

"I don't like to be disappointed, and I also don't want to disappoint. I love my husband and family too much to want to take drugs and I don't like the idea of aging prematurely because of a drug addiction. Moreover, the cost of drugs and addiction is too high a price to pay." - Emily, LiHoSingaporeansAgainstDrugs

I had quite an enjoyable time sharing my life as an Enforcement Officer and with that, my takeover has come to an end. My colleague from another unit will be continuing with CNB247 series so you can expect more BTS (behind-the-scenes) posts soon. Thank you all for the support. Here's James signing off. Till next time!

Singapore joins the world to commemorate the World Drug Day on 26 Jun. This is a special day that the United Nations has dedicated to raise awareness of the major problem that illicit drugs represent to society. This year, we have produced the commemorative stylus wristbands to commemorate the World Drug Day. Our DanceWorks! participants were the lucky few to have received it before they were distributed officially island wide on 26 Jun. Our student volunteers are out again today for the second round of distribution so look out for them and wear your band to show support for the anti-drug cause! antidrug worlddrugday antidrugcampaign sghappenings stylus drugfreesociety
